**The Esoteric Transmission of the True Man of Orthodox Yang’s Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure**

**Scripture Title:** *The Esoteric Transmission of the True Man of Orthodox Yang’s Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure* (abbreviated as *Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure*), three scrolls. Originally attributed to Zhongli Quan, transmitted by Lü Yan, dating from the Tang interregnum to the Five Dynasties period. Base text from the *Daoist Canon of the Orthodox Tradition*, *Great Clarity* section.

---

**Preface to the *Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure***

The Dao cannot be transmitted through words, nor can it be recorded by name. Since ancient times, those who ascended as immortals and attained the Dao have been many.

I, in my aspiration, have long admired the sages of old and cherished the Great Dao in my heart. Yet, as the times turned to the chaos of war and the world fell into peril, I first sought refuge, wandering among rivers, lakes, and mountain valleys. In retreat, I came to know my nature and turned my mind toward purity, stillness, and the subtle.

Having perused the alchemical classics and repeatedly consulted with fellow Daoists, I found that they spoke only of minor arts for nourishing life, never of the great Dao of true immortality. Then, within the stone cliffs of Mount Zhongnan, I obtained the *Scripture of the Numinous Treasure* in thirty scrolls:
- The *Upper Section: Golden Proclamations*, composed by the Primordial Beginning;
- The *Middle Section: Jade Records*, expounded by the Primordial Sovereign;
- The *Lower Section: True Source of Reality*, transmitted by the Most High.

Together, they comprise several thousand words. Through nights of vigil and days of diligent study, deep reflection led me to awaken to the truth: within yin there is yang, and within yang there is yin—this is the principle of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent, the pattern of the sun and moon’s union. Qi generates water, and water generates qi—this is also the principle of the heart and kidneys’ communion.

By comparing the images of things, the Dao is not distant from humanity. Matching *jia* and *geng* confirms the precision of the golden elixir. Extracting and augmenting *mao* and *you* naturally ensures the accuracy of the fire times. Red lead and black lead, when thoroughly refined, do not form the great medicine. Golden liquor and jade liquor, only at the culmination, become the returned elixir.

From non-being into being, one must ever hold the mind of martial endeavor. From below ascending to the heights, one gradually enters the realm of the subtle and formless. Drawing out lead and adding mercury dissolves the yin of the two eights. Exchanging bones and refining form causes the yang of the nine threes to grow. The clarity or turbidity of the water’s source is discerned at the moment of *ji ji* (completion). The inner vision of true emptiness is recognized on the day of *zuo wang* (sitting in forgetfulness).

The profound subtleties of the mysterious mechanism cannot be fully expressed in written methods. The wondrous principles of the Numinous Treasure may be employed to transcend the mundane and enter sagehood. Thus, they are synthesized into the three vehicles’ methods, titled *Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure*.

The sacred words of the Great Dao dare not be kept for private use. I transmit them to Dongbin, and when the Dao is achieved, do not conceal them—pass them on to those who come after.

—Preface by the True Man of Orthodox Yang, Zhongli Quan

**Scroll One of *The Esoteric Transmission of the True Man of Orthodox Yang’s Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure***

Composed by the True Man of Orthodox Yang, Zhongli Quan
Transmitted by the True Man of Pure Yang, Lü Yan (Dongbin)

**Four Gates of the Lesser Vehicle’s Method for Peace and Longevity**
**First Gate: Harmonizing Yin and Yang**

The *Jade Scripture* states: The Great Dao has no form, and cannot be perceived by sight or hearing. The Great Dao has no name, and cannot be measured by calculations or reckoning. It gives rise to form through the Dao, and names are established based on form. The greatest of names are Heaven and Earth. Heaven attains the Qian Dao and accumulates qi, covering all below. Earth attains the Kun Dao and supports substance, bearing all above. Between the covering and bearing, above and below are separated by eighty-four thousand li, and their qi and substance cannot interact. Heaven seeks Qian within Kun and returns to the center of Earth, its yang carrying yin upward. Earth seeks Kun within Qian and returns to the center of Heaven, its yin embracing yang downward. With each ascent and descent, they move through the Dao, and thus Heaven and Earth endure forever.

The *True Origin* states: Between Heaven and Earth, that which is close to above is yang; from above downward forty-two thousand li is called the yang position. That which is close to below is yin; from below upward forty-two thousand li is called the yin position. Once forms and names exist, they cannot escape measurement. Consider one year: four seasons, eight nodes, twenty-four qi, seventy-two hou, three hundred sixty days, and four thousand three hundred twenty periods. Twelve periods make one day, five days make one hou, three hou make one qi, two qi make one node, two nodes make one season, and four seasons make one year. The year begins with the Winter Solstice node, at which time yang ascends from within Earth. Each qi lasts fifteen days, ascending seven thousand li. Three qi make one node, one node forty-five days, with yang ascending a total of twenty-one thousand li. Two nodes make one season, one season ninety days, with yang ascending a total of forty-two thousand li, reaching precisely the center of Heaven and Earth, where yang meets the yin position. At this point, yang is half within yin, its qi becoming warm, corresponding to the Spring Equinox node. Beyond this, yang ascends into the yang position, now truly gaining qi and ascending, just as after forty-five days comes the Beginning of Summer. After the Beginning of Summer, forty-five days bring the Summer Solstice. At the Summer Solstice node, yang has ascended a total of eighty-four thousand li to reach Heaven, where yang is within yang, its qi hot. Accumulated yang generates yin, and one yin arises within two yang. Beginning with the Summer Solstice node, yin descends from within Heaven. Each qi lasts fifteen days, descending seven thousand li. Three qi make one node, one node forty-five days, with yin descending a total of twenty-one thousand li. Two nodes make one season, one season ninety days, with yin descending a total of forty-two thousand li to reach the center of Heaven and Earth, where yin meets the yang position. At this time, yin is half within yang, its qi becoming cool, corresponding to the Autumn Equinox node. Beyond this, yin descends into the yin position, now truly gaining qi and descending, just as after forty-five days comes the Beginning of Winter. After the Beginning of Winter, forty-five days bring the Winter Solstice. At the Winter Solstice node, yin has descended a total of eighty-four thousand li to reach Earth, where yin is within yin, its qi cold. Accumulated yin generates yang, and one yang arises within two yin. After the Winter Solstice, one yang ascends again, circulating endlessly as before, never deviating from the Dao.

At the Winter Solstice, yang is born, ascending to return to Heaven. At the Summer Solstice, yin is born, descending to return to Earth. When yang ascends to Heaven at the Summer Solstice, one yin arrives; when yin descends to Earth at the Winter Solstice, one yang arrives—hence the term "Winter Solstice." After yang ascends above, it passes the Spring Equinox to enter the yang position, departing from the yin position; yin descends below, passing the Autumn Equinox to enter the yin position, departing from the yang position—hence the terms "Spring Equinox" and "Autumn Equinox." After yang ascends at the Winter Solstice, from above downward, yin does not cease descending; the descending yin is merely the residual yin within yang, dissipating within the yang position. Even if it descends to its proper position and encounters ascending yang, its qi is exhausted. After yin descends at the Summer Solstice, from below upward, yang does not cease ascending; the ascending yang is merely the residual yang within yin, dissipating within the yin position. Even if it ascends to its proper position and encounters descending yin, its qi is exhausted. The ascent and descent of yin and yang, above and below, do not exceed eighty-four thousand li, and their coming and going cannot escape three hundred sixty days. Through the four qi of warmth, coolness, cold, and heat, one recognizes yin and yang; through the eight nodes of yang ascending and yin descending, one understands Heaven and Earth. Measuring this with the celestial mechanism, one may grasp the remnants of the Great Dao’s thread. If one relies on superficial learning to weigh the Dao of Heaven and Earth, how can calculations ever comprehend it?

For example: The Dao gives birth to the myriad things, and Heaven and Earth are the greatest among them. Humans are the most spiritually endowed among things, and when seeking the Dao separately, humans are akin to Heaven and Earth. The heart is likened to Heaven, the kidneys to Earth; the liver is the yang position, the lungs the yin position. The distance between heart and kidneys is eight cun and four fen, comparable to the space between Heaven’s covering and Earth’s bearing. Qi is likened to yang, and fluids to yin. The hours of *zi* and *wu* correspond to the Summer and Winter Solstice nodes; the hours of *mao* and *you* correspond to the Spring and Autumn Equinox nodes. One day is likened to one year, and the eight trigrams’ hours of the day correspond to the eight nodes. At the *zi* hour, qi is born within the kidneys; at the *mao* hour, qi reaches the liver. The liver is yang, and its qi flourishes as yang ascends into the yang position—this is the analogy of the Spring Equinox. At the *wu* hour, qi reaches the heart, and accumulated qi generates fluids—this is the analogy of yang ascending to Heaven at the Summer Solstice, where yin is born. At the *wu* hour, fluids are born within the heart; at the *you* hour, fluids reach the lungs.

The lungs are yin, and their fluids flourish as yin descends into the yin position—this is the analogy of the Autumn Equinox. At the *zi* hour, fluids reach the kidneys, and accumulated fluids generate qi—this is the analogy of yin descending to Earth at the Winter Solstice, where yang is born. Circulating endlessly, like the cycles of the sun and moon, without loss or deficiency, one may thereby prolong life.

The *True Formula* states: Heaven and Earth attain unity through the Dao, yet upon entering, one receives form from father and mother. Within form, form is born, and one drifts ever farther from the Dao. After the fetus is complete and qi is full, the six desires and seven emotions dissipate primordial yang, causing true qi to scatter and flee. Though qi and fluids naturally generate one another, they no longer follow Heaven and Earth’s ascent and descent. With each exhalation, primordial qi departs; with each inhalation, primordial qi enters, connecting with Heaven and Earth’s qi. Yet once drawn in, it cannot be retained—following the breath, it departs again. The qi of one’s own palace is instead seized by Heaven and Earth. Thus, scattered qi struggles to generate fluids, and scant fluids struggle to generate qi.

When qi is at its peak, employ the *mao* trigram in daily practice: inhale more and exhale less, forcibly retaining it in the abdomen. That which naturally ascends from below does not exit; that which enters from without temporarily abides. The two qi converge, accumulating to generate the fluids of the five viscera. The more one returns to the origin, the greater the accumulation. With daily cultivation and persistent effort, results will appear in due course.

The *Essentials of the Dao* states: To meet the eldest son of yang, one must inhale more and exhale less. Let the children contend with one another, and in time, seek the true. This is the method of accumulating qi to generate fluids, and accumulating fluids to generate qi—matching and pairing qi and fluids to engender one another. In practice, no more than a year is needed; with concentrated effort, one achieves threefold progress in one. A hundred days as a term, and signs appear within ten. One gains appetite and dispels illness, clarity in head and eyes, lightness in heart and abdomen, strength with little fatigue. At times, the sound of wind and thunder arises within the abdomen—countless other signs cannot all be recorded.

Explanation: The "eldest son of yang" refers to *qian* seeking *xu* from *kun*, like qi ascending upward. The "son" is qi, rising from the kidneys. The "daughter" is fluid, descending from the heart. Their contention causes ascent and descent. By restraining qi, fluids are generated; when matched in balance, true water is naturally obtained after a time.

**Gathering and Dispersing Water and Fire, Second Scroll**

The *Golden Teachings* state: The Great Dao is lofty yet without superior—look up, and its summit cannot be seen. The Great Dao is lowly yet without inferior—look down, and its base cannot be seen. It has no beginning, so its origin cannot be perceived; it has no end, so its conclusion cannot be seen. Within the Great Dao, Heaven and Earth are born. Heaven and Earth possess the measures of high and low. Within Heaven and Earth, yin and yang exist, with their cycles of beginning and end. Observing upward and downward, one may fathom their mechanism. Contemplating beginning and end, calculating their measures, one may grasp their principles. From this, the Great Dao may be known.

The *True Origin* states: From the positions of Heaven and Earth above and below, one knows their height and depth. From the cycles of yin and yang’s beginning and end, one knows the sequence of Heaven’s Dao. Heaven and Earth do not depart from their measures, which conclude in one year. Yin and yang do not lose their proper order, dividing into the eight nodes. At the Winter Solstice, one yang is born; at the Spring Equinox, yang is half within yin. Beyond this, pure yang prevails, and yin is exhausted. At the Summer Solstice, yang reaches its extreme, and one yin is born—its ascent and descent follow as before. Though the cycles of above and below, beginning and end, do not fully encompass the Great Dao, they do not depart from its essence. To comprehend the Great Dao, one must model it upon Heaven and Earth and examine the proper order of yin and yang.

Analogy: The heart and kidneys are likened to Heaven and Earth; qi and fluids to yin and yang; one day to one year. The daily use of the *gen* trigram corresponds to the *Lichun* (Beginning of Spring) node in a year; the *qian* trigram to the *Lidong* (Beginning of Winter) node. Within Heaven and Earth, that which is closer to below is yin. From below upward, forty-two thousand *li* is called the yin position. At the Winter Solstice, yang is born and ascends; at the time of *Lichun*, yang rises within the yin position to twenty-one thousand *li*—this is yang’s struggle to overcome yin. Within Heaven and Earth, that which is closer to above is yang. From above downward, forty-two thousand *li* is called the yang position. At the Summer Solstice, yin is born and descends; at the time of *Lidong*, yin descends, departing sixty-three thousand *li* from Heaven and twenty-one thousand *li* from Earth—this is yin attaining its position and yang being cut off.

Within a year, *Lichun* corresponds to the *gen* trigram in a day’s hours. Kidney qi transmits downward to the bladder, weak and struggling to ascend within fluids. Within a year, *Lidong* corresponds to the *qian* trigram in a day’s hours. Heart fluids descend, about to return to the origin and re-enter the kidneys—this is the time of yin’s flourishing and yang’s severance.

The cause of human illness lies in the disharmony of yin and yang, with yang weak and yin excessive—thus, illness is common. The *True Formula* states: At *Lichun*, yang ascends from below; before long, yang is half within yin. At the *gen* trigram, qi is faint in the *chou* and *yin* hours. At *Lidong*, yin descends from above; before long, yin is half within yang. At the *qian* trigram, qi scatters in the *xu* and *hai* hours. Such is the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Yet humans, when qi is faint at the *gen* trigram, do not know the means to nurture qi; when qi scatters at the *qian* trigram, do not understand the principle of gathering qi. Day and night, the six desires and seven emotions dissipate primordial yang, causing true qi to weaken and scatter, true fluids to fail to generate. Thus, one cannot attain the longevity of Heaven and Earth—this is the reason.

Therefore, the ancients practiced *zhun* in the morning and *meng* in the evening, employing two trigrams daily to achieve long life in the world. *Zhun* in the morning takes the meaning of one yang coiled and unextended. For oneself, one nurtures and extends it, preventing dissipation.

At dusk, *meng* takes the meaning of an unenlightened child seeking me to attain brightness and abandon darkness—this is the principle of yin seeking yang. For oneself, one obscures and then illuminates it, preventing its dissipation.

Thus, at sunrise, when the *gen* trigram governs, one nurtures primordial qi. Do not let profit or fame stir the heart, nor let likes and dislikes disturb the mind. Instead, don a robe and sit in stillness to cultivate qi. Banish thoughts and forget emotions, gently performing *daoyin*. Alternately stretch and contract the hands and feet three to five times, so that the qi of the four limbs arises evenly, inwardly preserving primordial qi to ascend and gather at the heart’s palace. One may swallow saliva once or twice and rub the head and face twenty to thirty times, exhaling the foul, stagnant qi accumulated through the night. With time, one’s complexion will glow with radiance, and the skin will become lustrous.

The *gen* trigram nurtures primordial qi. Furthermore, at sunset, when the *qian* trigram governs, one gathers primordial qi. Enter a chamber and sit in stillness, swallowing qi and contracting the external kidneys. Swallowing qi draws the heart’s fire downward. Contracting the external kidneys gathers the bladder’s qi inward. The *qian* trigram gathers primordial qi. When the upper and lower kidney fires unite, the three fires merge into one, warming and replenishing the lower elixir field. Without fluids, one gathers qi to generate fluids; with fluids, one refines them to produce qi. This is called "gathering fire" or "the Supreme Unity containing true qi."

In the early morning, swallowing saliva, rubbing the face, and alternately stretching the hands and feet is called "dispersing fire" or "minor refinement of form." As the *Daoist Essentials* states:

> When blossoms wither and leaves fall in late autumn,
> The consort grows weary of ascending the high tower.
> To harmonize ruler and people,
> One must frequently gather after the feast.

This means drawing in the heart’s qi and gathering the bladder’s qi, preventing dissipation so they may unite with kidney qi to receive the qi of the *kan* trigram—the newly arisen qi from the sea. One must begin at the Winter Commencement solar term and continue until results appear. The practice should not exceed a year; the work of one merges into three, with a hundred days as the period and verification appearing in ten. The complexion will grow luminous, the skin full and joyful, the lower elixir field warm, urination reduced, the four limbs light and strong, the spirit clear and refreshed, and chronic illnesses entirely dissolved.

If one cherishes time and practices without weariness, even within the work of harmonizing yin and yang, slight results may appear. This method is then incorporated into daily practice, with the *gen* trigram added. When the three *yuan* of the *qian* trigram take effect, one ceases upon verification. The three *yuan* are *qian*, *gen*, and *zhen*.

A Commentary states: When flowers wither and leaves fall in late autumn, it is like the time when a person’s qi weakens at dusk—yang qi scatters and fails to ascend, hence the saying, “Too weary to climb the high tower.” The tower refers to the *chonglou* (double-storied structure). The heart is the sovereign fire, the bladder the ministerial fire; swallowing qi and drawing in the external kidneys cause the heart and external kidneys to unite their qi as one—this is called *hehui* (harmonious union). *Yan* means swallowing, and *shou* means drawing in.

If the morning practice is unbroken, this method becomes the foundation. **The Third: The Union of Dragon and Tiger**

The *Jingao* says: When the Great Primal first divided, there was the Great Beginning; within the Great Beginning was the Great Non-Being; within the Great Non-Being was the Great Void; within the Great Void was the Great Emptiness; and within the Great Emptiness was the Great Substance. The Great Substance is Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth, clear and turbid, take the form of an egg with a dark and yellow hue—merely one thing within the Great Emptiness. When yang ascends to the Heavenly Supreme Ultimate, it generates yin, which in profound obscurity embraces yang and descends. When yin descends to the Earthly Supreme Ultimate, it generates yang, which in a state of indistinctness bears yin and ascends. With one ascent and one descent—yin descending and yang ascending—Heaven and Earth follow the Dao, and the myriad things are born and formed.

The *Zhenyuan* says: Heaven is like an overturned basin, making it difficult for yang to ascend when it reaches its limit. Earth is like a stone slab, making it difficult for yin to penetrate when it reaches its limit. At the Winter Solstice, yang within the earth ascends; at the Summer Solstice, when it reaches Heaven, yang attains the Supreme Ultimate and generates yin. The reason yin is generated is that yang arises from within yin, emerging from the earth in a state of indistinctness—within qi there is water, though this water has no form. When the Summer Solstice reaches Heaven, it transforms into water; this is yang attaining the Supreme Ultimate and generating yin. At the Summer Solstice, yin within Heaven descends; at the Winter Solstice, when it reaches Earth, yin attains the Supreme Ultimate and generates yang. The reason yang is generated is that yin emerges from within yang, issuing from Heaven in a state of profound obscurity—within water there is qi, though this qi has no form. When the Winter Solstice reaches Earth, accumulated water generates qi; this is yin attaining the Supreme Ultimate and generating yang.

As an analogy: Compare the body’s exterior to the Great Emptiness, the heart and kidneys to Heaven and Earth, qi and fluids to yin and yang, and the hours of *zi* and *wu* to winter and summer. The *zi* hour corresponds to the *kan* trigram, when qi is born in the kidneys. The *wu* hour corresponds to the *li* trigram, when qi reaches the heart. When kidney qi and heart qi unite, the Supreme Ultimate generates fluid. The reason fluid is generated is that qi arises from within the kidneys—within qi there is true water, though this water has no form. When the *li* trigram reaches the heart and meets heart qi, the Supreme Ultimate generates fluid in this manner. When fluid is born in the heart (*li* trigram) and reaches the kidneys (*kan* trigram), the fluid unites with kidney water, and the Supreme Ultimate regenerates qi. The reason qi is generated is that fluid arises from within the heart—within fluid there is true qi, though this qi has no form. When the *kan* trigram reaches the kidneys and meets kidney water, the Supreme Ultimate generates qi in this manner. This can be likened to yang ascending and yin descending, reaching the Supreme Ultimate and generating one another. The yin and yang thus generated contain water within yang and qi within yin.

The *Zhenjue* says: Qi is born in the kidneys, and within qi there is true water. Fluid is born in the heart, and within fluid there is true qi. True water and true qi are the true Dragon and true Tiger. When yang reaches Heaven and struggles to ascend, the Supreme Ultimate generates yin. When yin reaches Earth and struggles to penetrate, the Supreme Ultimate generates yang. Such is the principle of Heaven and Earth. Only humans cannot compare to Heaven and Earth because the six desires and seven emotions, stirred by external things, scatter their original yang and dissipate their true qi. When kidney qi (*li* trigram) reaches the heart, the spirit and consciousness settle inwardly; the breath enters slowly through the nose and exits gently, continuous yet subtle. Saliva fills the mouth—do not spit or swallow it. Naturally, kidney qi and heart qi unite, and the Supreme Ultimate generates fluid. When fluid unites with true water, true qi clings to fluid, and true water clings to qi. Though they are not inherently united, within fluid there is true qi, and within qi there is true water. They intermingle, cling to one another, and descend—this is called the *jiaogou* (union) of Dragon and Tiger. If the firing times are without error and the withdrawal and addition are appropriate, after three hundred days of nurturing, the true embryo forms into the great medicine. This is the foundation of refining the body, burning away the physical form, attaining the origin, and transcending the mundane.

The *Daoyao* says: When the primal qi first returns to its original movement, true yang is about to reach the *li* palace. Seize the true Dragon and true Tiger—within the Jade Pool, spring waters flow gently. This is to prevent the leakage of original qi and the loss of true water beyond the body. If qi scatters, fluid is difficult to generate; if fluid is scant, there is no true qi. If qi and water do not unite, how can the great medicine be formed? During this year, take the Winter Solstice as the beginning; within the day, take the *li* trigram as the period. For those who embrace the Dao in later years, whose roots are unstable, and who suffer from depletion and insufficiency of qi, ten years of depletion require one year of practice to restore—this is called *caibu huandan* (gathering and replenishing the elixir). If the replenishment exceeds the required measure, cease this method and practice *shuihuo jiji* (the harmony of water and fire). This can prolong life and extend years—it is called the *renxian* (human immortal). The effects of the practice cannot be fully recorded. If the replenishment is sufficient, sweet saliva will arise in the mouth, the mind’s afflictions will vanish, desires will not stir, the hundred bones will be free of illness, and within the darkness, the radiance of the spirit will appear before the eyes like lightning. Taking the Winter Solstice as the starting point and practicing the method for three hundred days, the embryonic immortal is complete.

A Commentary states: Externally, the *wu* hour is the *li* palace, and the great yang is the true yang. Within the person, the heart is the *li* palace, and original yang is the true Dragon; the true Tiger is the water within the kidneys. The true Dragon is the qi within heart fluid; the mouth is the Jade Pool, and saliva is the spring water.

**The Fourth: Refining the Elixir**

The *Jingao* says: Heaven and Earth are the forms of the great Dao. Yin and yang are the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Cold, heat, warmth, and coolness—within form there is qi.

Clouds, mist, rain, and dew—within qi there are images. Earth’s qi ascends, rising to become clouds and dispersing to become rain. Heaven’s qi descends, scattering into mist and condensing into dew. When accumulated yin exceeds, dew transforms into frost and then snow. When accumulated yang exceeds, mist becomes smoke, clouds, and rosy dawn. Within yin, yang lies concealed; if yang qi does not descend, it strikes and collides to generate thunder and lightning. Within yang, yin lies concealed; if yin qi does not congeal, it hardens to produce hail and graupel. When yin and yang fail to unite, they oppose each other to generate lightning. When yin and yang are mismatched, their chaotic union produces rainbows. Accumulated true yang forms spirits, which adorn the heavens as stars. Accumulated true yin forms shapes, which strengthen the earth as soil and stone. The greatest of stars are the sun and moon; the most precious of soil and stone are gold and jade. Yin and yang manifest in the visible forms of the sun and moon above, and gold and jade below.

*The True Origin* states: Yin cannot generate without yang; yang cannot complete without yin. Accumulated yang becomes spirit, adorning the heavens in grandeur—such are the sun and moon. The sun and moon are true yang that achieves completion through true yin. Accumulated yin forms shapes, strengthening the earth in preciousness—such are gold and jade. Gold and jade are true yin that attains generation through true yang.

Practice during the *xu* and *hai* hours: in the *Li* trigram, gather the medicine; in the *Qian* trigram, advance the fire. As an analogy: true yang corresponds to the true qi within heart fluid; true yin corresponds to the true water within kidney qi. True water cannot generate without true qi; true qi cannot complete without true water. When true water and true qi harmonize in the *Li* trigram—above the heart and below the lungs—they cling to each other like mother and child, or husband and wife in mutual affection.

From *Li* to *Dui*, when the *Dui* trigram’s yin flourishes and yang weakens, it resembles the moon’s waning crescent or gold and jade hidden in darkness, awaiting the dawn when their measure is fulfilled to shine anew. Gold and jade, refined by yang to generate yin, become treasures when qi is sufficient—this is achieved by advancing yang to fullness. The sun and moon renew their brightness when their measure is fulfilled and they receive the soul. This is analogous to advancing the fire in the *Qian* trigram, refining yang without declining flame, so that yang perpetually regenerates through incremental addition.

*The True Formula* states: When the Dragon and Tiger unite in the *Li* trigram, it is called "gathering the medicine." When the time arrives at the *Qian* trigram, qi and fluid prepare to return to their origin, generating above the bladder, below the spleen and stomach, before the kidneys, behind the navel, to the left of the liver, to the right of the lungs, to the right of the small intestine, and to the left of the large intestine. At this moment, spleen qi flourishes and lung qi thrives, while heart qi ceases and liver qi weakens. True qi, originally united with yang qi, now finds yang qi diminished and has nothing to cling to—practice at this time is laborious, yet the gathering and union must occur precisely then.

With spirit and awareness inwardly guarded, the breath flows gently through the nose. The abdomen subtly presses against the navel and kidneys; when the heat becomes too intense, slightly relax the pressure, gently restraining the navel. Before heat arises, tighten the restraint; as warmth grows, maintain steady pressure, allowing the mind to roam freely until it fills the cosmos—this is called "restraining the Yang Gate to refine the elixir." Thus, qi does not ascend but unites with true water, passing through the spleen palace and, with each breath, circulating into the life palace of the Yellow Court. As qi and fluid transform, they first become essence, then pearl, then mercury, then cinnabar, and finally gold—this is called the Golden Elixir. Its achievement is no small matter.

*The Essentials of the Dao* states: Gathering the medicine relies on the Jade Hare—heart qi is the medicine, and kidney water is the Jade Hare. Union must be facilitated by the Yellow Matron. The so-called *jade essence* originates from kidney *qi*, ascending to the heart to merge with heart *qi*. When the two *qi* intersect and pass the *Double Towers*, the mouth is sealed, and the *saliva* fills the *Jade Pool*. Swallowing it is called *jade essence returning cinnabar*; refining it upward is called *jade essence refining form*. This essence arises from the kidneys yet is born in the heart—analogous to stone emerging from earth and jade from stone.

The so-called *golden essence* occurs when kidney *qi* merges with heart *qi* without ascending, instead steaming the lungs. The lungs, as the *flowery canopy*, enshroud the two *qi*. Drawing lung essence at dawn, one guides it from the *Lower Field* upward through the *Weilü* cavity, calling it *flying golden radiance into the brain* to replenish the *Mud Pill Palace*. Once replenished, it descends from above back to the *Lower Field*, called *golden essence returning cinnabar*. After returning to the *Lower Field*, it ascends again, suffusing the four limbs and rising front and back—this is *golden essence refining form*, also illustrating how metal is born from earth.

For those refining form and flying golden radiance, one must be in a pure chamber, strictly avoiding wind and sunlight. From afar, burn incense and silently invoke: *"Three Pure Ones and Supreme Sages, may your servant dwell long in the world, transmit the Great Dao, and teach others. First, I shall practice the method of refining form, to transcend cold and heat, abstain from grain, and escape beyond yin and yang."* After the incantation, swallow.

*The True Formula* states: *"The cavity behind the tailbone is the Lower Pass; the spine’s sides are the Middle Pass; below the brain is the Upper Pass."* Begin by flying golden radiance to open the *Three Passes*. The kidneys correspond to earth, the heart to heaven, ascending to the crown to mirror the *Nine Heavens*. Jade essence refining form rises from the heart to the crown, connecting the *Nine Heavens*. After three hundred days of swallowing, the great elixir is complete, the *embryonic immortal* perfected, and true *qi* is born. Rising forward follows the old path of jade essence refining form; rising backward follows the old path of flying golden radiance. As golden radiance and jade essence circulate, verification begins with the *Kan* trigram. Afterward, rise once to the crown, lightly cover the ears with both hands, and inwardly observe. As prescribed, gently swallow the saliva. Press the tongue against the teeth, seal the *Jade Pool*, and await the essence from the upper palate before swallowing. After swallowing, rise again, concluding at the *Gen* trigram. In spring and winter, swallow once per two risings; in autumn and summer, swallow once per five risings. Each swallow’s count should not exceed fifty in autumn and summer, nor one hundred in spring and winter. After swallowing, rise forward to suffuse the head, face, limbs, and fingers until the *qi* is abundant. Rise again, concluding at the *Li* trigram. Thereafter, rising backward to swallow saliva is called *golden essence returning cinnabar*. After returning cinnabar, rise forward again—this is *golden essence refining form*. From the *Gen* trigram onward, refine form until the *Li* trigram. At the *Dui* trigram, restrain the *Yang Pass* until the *Qian* trigram. Rising backward to the crown, then descending, is called *golden essence returning cinnabar*. The *qi* of the golden elixir rising forward from below is *golden essence refining form*. When golden blossoms appear like jade trees, if the golden essence returning cinnabar has not yet reached the *Lower Origin* but rises both forward and backward, it is called *fire rising to incinerate the body*—this occurs when golden essence returning cinnabar and refining form rise simultaneously. In such practices, one must be meticulous, resolute, and unwavering, proceeding only until verification is achieved.

*The Dao Essentials* states: *"After rising, close the ears all night, drink the golden waves in due time, and feast until reaching Qingzhou before stopping. At sunset, listen again to the yang song."* The explanation: *"After rising, close the ears all night"* refers to the practice of golden essence returning cinnabar, where one must fly golden radiance from behind the elbow, striking the *Three Passes*. As the *qi* rises, swiftly cover the ears with both hands. The ears are the gates of kidney *qi*; one must prevent its leakage outward, ensuring it enters the brain. *"Drink the golden waves in due time"* means that upon sensing the *qi* enter the brain, immediately follow the previous method: nod the head, curve the neck, retract the tongue, and press it against the upper palate. The clear, sweet water that emerges is the sign—sweet as honey. At the *Gen* trigram, fly golden radiance and swallow once, concluding at the *Zhen* trigram. *Qingzhou* corresponds to the *Zhen* trigram; *sunset* to the *Dui* trigram. *"Listen again to the yang song"* refers to restraining the *Yang Pass* from the *Dui* trigram to the *Qian* trigram, using the *Li* trigram daily without gathering medicine.

After drinking all night, fire rises, ascending forward and lifting backward to incinerate the body. Though unbound by years or months, within each day lies heaven and earth. The explanation: This is the method of golden essence refining form. *"After drinking all night, fire rises"* follows the previous method of golden essence returning cinnabar, where refining form at the *Gen* trigram ignites the fire. *"Ascending forward and lifting backward"* refers to flying golden radiance to ignite the fire. During jade essence refining form, first rise backward to guide golden radiance into the crown, then return cinnabar and rise forward to refine form—this distinguishes the method of golden essence refining form. When flying golden radiance ignites fire into the crown, rise forward to refine form. Rising both forward and backward is called *incinerating the body*. When refining cinnabar with fire, adjust the count according to the four seasons. This practice is not bound by years, months, days, or hours; one must be meticulous, single-minded, secluded, and withdrawn. *"Within each day lies heaven and earth"* means that before noon, one refines *Qian*; after noon, one refines *Kun*. From the body’s front and back: the abdomen is *Kun*, the back is *Qian*. *"Refining Qian before noon"* refers to flying golden radiance from behind the elbow and rising forward to refine form. *"Refining Kun after noon"* refers to restraining the *Yang Pass* from the *Dui* trigram to the *Qian* trigram. This method should only be practiced after verifying jade essence returning cinnabar and refining form, with meticulous seclusion, burning incense, and strict adherence.

When refining the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir and subsequently tempering the form by restraining the *Yang Pass*, only after a full year may one proceed to *fenshen* (incineration of the body). *Fenshen* is the refinement of form preceding the *Kan* trigram. Regarding the body’s front and back: the abdomen is *Kun*, the back is *Qian*. For *fenshen*, refine *Qian* before noon and refine *Kun* after noon while restraining the *Yang Pass*. In refining *Qian*, the fire rises from below to above, activating both front and back. In winter and summer, completion occurs in three days; after five days, the method of *jiji* (Completion) is applied to prevent excess, ensuring the Golden Elixir remains supple. This is the ignition of *fenshen* fire within the central throat. Cease only upon verification.

The inner will becomes pure and lofty, merging with the Great Void; the hun and shen spirits do not wander, banishing dreams and sleep. The *Yang* essence solidifies the body, fortifying the spirit’s abode. One becomes impervious to the cold and heat of the four seasons, and one’s countenance naturally transforms. Even when facing ordinary people—though they may be wealthy or noble—one perceives only foul odors, for they remain of mortal bone and vulgar form. When merit and practice are fulfilled, the Three Clarities’ true registers are secretly conferred. The transformations of yin and yang, the fortunes and misfortunes of human affairs, and the movements of spirits—all may be foreknown. The eyes meet only dust and clutter, yet the mind severs all mundane realms. True *qi* fills the body, eliminating the need for food and drink. Extraordinary *qi* emanates a golden hue, and the immortal flesh rivals jade blossoms. Wherever one goes or stays, divine beings appear of their own accord, obeying commands as if by one’s own will.

When true *qi* becomes purely *Yang*, it can dry external water. The above describes the verification of refining form with the Golden Liquor after the Returned Elixir. All that precedes is the secret to longevity and immortality.

**Morning Audience (Eighth)**

**The Golden Proclamation** states:
At the primal division of the singular *qi*, the Great Dao took form and arrayed the Two Modes. Once the Two Modes settled into their positions, the Great Dao acquired names and divided into the Five Emperors. The Five Emperors, each dwelling in distinct lands, guarded their respective directions; the five directions, each governed by distinct *qi*, each guarded one celestial stem. The Azure Emperor’s stems *jia* and *yi* received the nine *qi* of Heaven’s true Wood virtue. The Vermilion Emperor’s stems *bing* and *ding* received the three *qi* of Heaven’s true Fire virtue. The White Emperor’s stems *geng* and *xin* received the seven *qi* of Heaven’s true Metal virtue. The Black Emperor’s stems *ren* and *gui* received the five *qi* of Heaven’s true Water virtue. The Yellow Emperor’s stems *wu* and *ji* received the singular *qi* of Heaven’s true Earth virtue. From the One arises the True One; the True One emerges through Earth, thus all things are born and completed in Earth. The Five Phases are generated and completed in the One. The Dao of the true origin is entirely born of the singular *qi*.

**The Jade Book of Registers** states:
One, three, five, seven, nine—these are the Dao’s divisions manifesting as numbers. Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—these are the Dao’s transformations manifesting as images. East, West, South, North, Center—these are the Dao’s arrangements manifesting as positions. Azure, white, vermilion, yellow, black—these are the Dao’s dispersals manifesting as substances. When numbers return to the unnumbered, images revert to the imageless, positions reach the positionless, and substances return to the unsubstantial—then to attain the Dao’s unnumbered state, one must not divide it; to attain the Dao’s imageless state, one must not transform it; to attain the Dao’s positionless state, one must not arrange it; to attain the Dao’s unsubstantial state, one must not solidify it. The unnumbered is the Dao’s source; the imageless is the Dao’s root; the positionless is the Dao’s truth; the unsubstantial is the Dao’s subtlety.

**The True Origin** states:
Once the Dao’s origin divided, it descended from root to branch. Those who awaken to its truth cultivate truth through truth, and when truth is internal, external truth naturally responds. Those who recognize its subtlety attain subtlety through subtlety, and when subtlety is internal, external subtlety naturally responds. Heaven and Earth grasp the Dao’s truth, yet their truth remains unmanifest, thus they have not escaped position. Heaven and Earth grasp the Dao’s subtlety, yet their subtlety remains unmanifest, thus they have not escaped substance. With substance, images may be sought; with position, numbers may be deduced. Within the realm of Heaven and Earth, amid the ten thousand things, none is more noble than humanity. Since Heaven and Earth possess images to be sought, we know their substance, *qi*, and water. Since Heaven and Earth possess numbers to be deduced, we know their positions, far and near. By examining this, we see that the Dao is not distant from humanity.

For analogy: Heaven and Earth have the Five Emperors, just as humans have the five viscera. The Azure Emperor, *jia-yi* Wood—*jia* as Yang, *yi* as Yin—corresponds to the liver’s *qi* and fluids. The Black Emperor, *ren-gui* Water—*ren* as Yang, *gui* as Yin—corresponds to the kidneys’ *qi* and fluids. The Yellow Emperor, *wu-ji* Earth—*wu* as Yang, *ji* as Yin—corresponds to the spleen’s *qi* and fluids. The Vermilion Emperor, *bing-ding* Fire—*bing* as Yang, *ding* as Yin—corresponds to the heart’s *qi* and fluids. The White Emperor, *geng-xin* Metal—*geng* as Yang, *xin* as Yin—corresponds to the lungs’ *qi* and fluids. Though the seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter differ, the flourishing of the heart, lungs, liver, and kidneys occurs in specific months.

**The True Formula** states:
During the three months of spring, the liver’s *qi* flourishes. When the liver flourishes, the parents’ true *qi*, following the celestial movements, resides in the liver. On Wood days (*jia-yi*), rescue Earth at the hours of *chen*, *xu*, *chou*, and *wei* by kindling the fire to refine the spleen’s *qi*. On other days, during the *dui* trigram hours, diminish Metal to deplete the lungs’ *qi*—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *kan* trigram hours, kindle the fire according to method to refine the kidneys’ *qi*. During the *zhen* trigram hours, enter the chamber, emphasizing inhalation over exhalation as optimal; prolonged breath retention is secondary. Count to one thousand breaths as the measure. At that time, internally visualize according to method, concentrating the mind with closed eyes. Azure light will naturally appear, gradually ascending the body to enter the *niwan* palace. From *yin* to *chen*, fill the *zhen* trigram. Exceeding one thousand breaths is especially excellent. If the breath becomes urgent, gradually reduce it, exhaling and then pausing—do not force continuity.

During the three months of summer, the heart’s *qi* flourishes. When the heart flourishes, the parents’ true *qi*, following the celestial movements, resides in the heart. On Fire days (*bing-ding*), rescue Metal during the *dui* trigram hours by kindling the fire to refine the lungs’ *qi*. On other days, during the *kan* trigram hours, diminish Water to deplete the kidneys’ *qi*—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *zhen* trigram hours, kindle the fire according to method to refine the liver’s *qi*. During the *li* trigram hours, enter the chamber and practice breath regulation as before. Vermilion light will naturally appear, gradually ascending the body to enter the *niwan* palace. From *si* to *wei*, fill the *li* trigram. Exceeding one thousand breaths is especially excellent; the method is as described above.

During the three months of autumn, the lungs’ *qi* flourishes. When the lungs flourish, the parents’ true *qi*, following the celestial movements, resides in the lungs. On Metal days (*geng-xin*), rescue Wood during the *zhen* trigram hours by kindling the fire to refine the liver’s *qi*. On other days, during the *li* trigram hours, diminish Fire to deplete the heart’s *qi*—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *xun* trigram hours, kindle the fire according to method to refine the spleen’s *qi*. During the *dui* trigram hours, enter the chamber and practice as before. White light will naturally appear, gradually ascending the body to enter the *niwan* palace. From *shen* to *xu*, fill the *dui* trigram.

During the three months of winter, the kidneys’ *qi* flourishes. When the kidneys flourish, the parents’ true *qi*, following the celestial movements, resides in the kidneys. On Water days (*ren-gui*), rescue Fire during the *li* trigram hours by kindling the fire to refine the heart’s *qi*. On other days, during the hours of *chen*, *xu*, *chou*, and *wei*, diminish Earth to deplete the spleen’s *qi*—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *dui* trigram hours, kindle the fire according to method to refine the lungs’ *qi*. During the *kan* trigram hours, enter the chamber and practice as before. Black light will naturally appear, gradually ascending the body to enter the *niwan* palace. From *hai* to *chou*, fill the *kan* trigram.

Explanation states: In spring, refine the liver for a thousand breaths, and green *qi* emerges. During the final eighteen days of spring, one need not practice as before; instead, adopt the method of settled breathing and sit in stillness throughout the day to nourish the spleen and refine one’s true *qi*. Only then may one kindle the fire during the *kan* trigram hours to refine the kidneys, lest their true *qi* be depleted.

In summer, refine the heart for a thousand breaths, and red *qi* emerges. During the final eighteen days of summer, one need not practice as before; instead, adopt the method of settled breathing and sit in stillness throughout the day, nurturing and refining as before. Only then may one kindle the fire during the *kan* trigram hours as previously described.

In autumn, refine the lungs for a thousand breaths, and white *qi* emerges. During the final eighteen days of autumn, one need not practice as before; instead, adopt the method of settled breathing and sit in stillness throughout the day, nurturing and refining as before. Only then may one kindle the fire during the *kan* trigram hours as previously described.

In winter, refine the kidneys for a thousand breaths, and black *qi* emerges. During the final eighteen days of winter, one need not practice as before; instead, adopt the method of settled breathing and sit in stillness throughout the day, nurturing and refining as before. Only then may one kindle the fire during the *kan* trigram hours as previously described.

When yellow *qi* forms into light, silently observe myriad rays encircling the body.

The method of settled breathing does not lie in forcefully restraining or tightly closing the breath. Rather, it should be continuous as if present, applied without strain, moving from non-being into being, allowing it to reside naturally.

The method of gathering the elixir involves holding the saliva and clasping the hands firmly to prevent the heart’s true *qi* from scattering.

When entering the chamber, one must close the door in a secluded and quiet dwelling, far from chickens, dogs, women, and all disturbing influences. Slightly open a small aperture to discern objects, but ensure neither wind nor sunlight enters, nor any sounds from the left or right.

One should settle the mind and still all thoughts, casting aside worldly concerns. Internally and externally, all must be serene, with nothing to disturb the intent. For the yang spirit is newly gathered and the true *qi* just congealing, one must tend to it as a newborn infant.

Before half the work is complete, burn incense and silently pray to Heaven day and night. Those who conceal themselves in the mountains and forests, with half their merit accomplished, become earthly immortals.

Kneeling and bowing with reverence, silently pray to Heaven, dwelling in remote caves or secluded grottoes. Establish great merit for the world, and remove great harm for the people. Those who remain hidden become heavenly immortals. After three bows are completed, sit in stillness, forgetting all schemes, and proceed with this method.

One must still follow the preceding methods step by step to witness verification. If one merely engages in this practice casually, one may labor in vain and see no fruition, ending only as a ghostly immortal whose yin spirit departs the body.

*The Essential Dao* states: In practicing this method, there is no fixed duration of years, months, or days. Follow the preceding method each month until verification is achieved, and the *qi* will naturally manifest. One must be diligent and unwavering, abandoning all external affairs and focusing the will within the chamber. Discern the proper times and employ two pure yang youths. Alternatively, take on disciples, but beware of betrayal or reversal. After serving for a thousand days, one may complete a single cycle of *qi*. One can overcome ten with one, and in a hundred days, signs of progress will appear. In five hundred days, the *qi* will be complete, allowing one to practice inner observation of *qi* afterward. Gather the yang spirit to merge with celestial spirits, refining it to unite with the Dao, entering sagehood and transcending the mundane.

The verification of refining *qi* lies in feeling the body exceedingly harmonious, often ascending as if in flight, with the elixir’s light penetrating the bones and extraordinary fragrance filling the chamber. Next, in stillness, observe outwardly—purple radiance fills the eyes. Looking downward from the crown, golden light envelops the body. Strange signs and verifications are too numerous to record in full.

This is the ninth method of inner observation.

The *Golden Proclamation* states: The Great Dao is fundamentally formless, residing within *qi*. Its vastness knows no bounds, and no thing can contain it. The Great Dao is fundamentally functionless, yet operates through things. Its depth is unfathomable, and no principle can exhaust it. Speaking of the Dao in terms of its body, it then begins to have distinctions of inner and outer. Speaking of the Dao in terms of its function, it then begins to have a basis for observation and perception. Observe inwardly and not outwardly, and though nothing external remains unexamined, clarity is attained within. Observe the spirit and not the form, and though no form is left unprepared, the spirit becomes visible.

The *True Origin* states: With one mind observe the myriad things, and the myriad things are not said to be in excess. With the myriad things disturbing the one *qi*, the one *qi* is not said to be insufficient. When the one *qi* returns to the mind, the mind cannot be seized by things. When the one mind moves the one *qi*, the *qi* cannot be enslaved by methods. When the source of the mind is clear and penetrating, one illumination shatters ten thousand delusions, and one is unaware of the existence of things. When *qi* wages a fierce struggle, ten thousand sensations are stilled in a single breath, and one is unaware of the existence of methods. Things are no-things, returning to the original image. Methods are no-methods, thereby fulfilling the true nature of self-attainment.

For analogy: form arises from image, and names are established from form. With names, one infers their numbers; with numbers, one grasps their principles. Such is the discourse of analogy. Yet the supreme and void Dao transcends all things, and nothing can serve as a comparison. What can be likened is this: as in human cultivation, the seasons and sequences are without error, and accomplishments follow in order. The harmonious *qi* congeals without dispersing; the true nature, utterly serene, is without action. The spirit merges with the Dao and returns to spontaneity. At this juncture, take non-mind as mind. How then is one to respond to things? Take non-things as things. How then is one to employ methods? In true joy, one is blissfully unaware of having a body. Gradually entering the Dao of non-action, one reaches the realm of the subtle and imperceptible, becoming a guest who has entered sagehood and transcended the mundane.

The *True Formula* states: This method accords with the Dao, resembling the principle of visualization often discussed, or like the moment when Chan monks enter samadhi. Choose an auspicious site to establish a chamber. Kneel, pay respects, burn incense, sit upright with legs crossed, let the hair down, loosen the robes, clench the fists to retain spirit, empty the mind, and close the eyes. Before noon, slightly raise the body to kindle the fire and refine *qi*. After noon, slightly gather the body to concentrate the fire and burn the elixir. Regardless of day or night, when the spirit is clear and *qi* harmonious, one naturally delights in sitting. During sitting, if sounds are heard, do not listen; if visions appear, do not acknowledge them, and the illusory realms will disperse of themselves. If one acknowledges the illusory realms, demonic forces will intensify and not retreat. Immediately, slightly gather the body, then stretch the waist; afterward, slightly recline the chest without stretching the waist. Wait briefly until the fire rises before and behind, then raise the body without moving—this is called "firing the body." When the fire rises, demonic forces scatter beyond the body, and yin evil does not enter the shell. Repeat this two or three times. Then visualize all between heaven and earth as a raging fire, entirely cool and devoid of things. Only then may one see carriages, horses, singing, dancing, canopies, silks, wealth, splendor, and joyous multitudes—processions in rows, five-colored clouds ascending, as if ascending to the celestial realms. Upon arriving there, one sees towering pavilions of jade green, courtyards stretching endlessly, pearls, jewels, gold, and jade scattered ungathered upon the ground, flowers, fruits, ponds, and pavilions beyond count. Suddenly, exotic fragrances arise on all sides, and the sounds of music and revelry fill the air. Guests and friends sit in full assembly, with delicacies of land and sea laid out. Laughter and conversation abound, celebrating great peace, and precious objects are exchanged as gifts. At this moment, though these are not yin ghosts or demonic forces, one must not regard them as auspicious. The true cultivator renounces external affairs, willingly endures solitude, conceals traces in rivers and lakes, or withdraws to secluded corners, cutting off thoughts and forgetting emotions, ever vigilant in conduct, enduring hardship and enjoying freedom. Once the work is accomplished and the method established, one may suddenly witness such splendor. Though not considering it a demonic illusion, one might mistake it for a true arrival in the celestial palace. Little does one know that the transcending of the mortal womb occurs within one’s own celestial palace atop the head. If one becomes attached and takes it for reality, failing to employ the method of transcendence, the yang spirit will remain within the body, and the embryonic immortal will not transform. One may then claim to have emerged above the dark paths, becoming an earthbound immortal, achieving longevity without death—but one cannot shed the mortal form to ascend as an immortal and return to the Three Isles as a celestial being. This is truly lamentable. Disciples must consider that though transcendence is difficult, it cannot be neglected.

The *Essentials of the Dao* states: The inexhaustible Dharma has already extinguished past faults.

**Transcendence: Tenth Method**

The *Golden Proclamation* states: The Dao is fundamentally non-being; to speak of it as being is not the Dao. The Dao is fundamentally void; to speak of it as substantial is not the Dao. Being formless, even questions and responses cannot apply to it. Being imageless, even seeing and hearing cannot apply to it. Taking the mysterious and subtle as the Dao, the mysterious and subtle still cannot escape the burdens of inquiry and perception. Taking the subtle and imperceptible as the Dao, one still cannot avoid the burdens of seeing and hearing. If even the subtle and imperceptible are not the Dao, then the Dao is also beyond knowing how it is so.

The *Jade Scripture* states: Its coming has a beginning, yet one does not know the beginning of the Great Dao. What is this? Its going has an end, yet one does not know the end of the Great Dao. What is this? Above the loftiest heights, though there is an "above," one does not know that above the Great Dao there is no limit. Below the deepest depths, though there is a "below," one does not know that below the Great Dao there is no end. Profound and unfathomable, it is called the Dao. It accords with what beings attain and arranges distinctions. The Dao of non-action cannot be exhausted.

The *True Formula* states: "Transcend" means transcending the mortal body to enter the ranks of sages. "Liberate" means shedding the mundane womb to become an immortal child.

When the spirit enters the qi-womb, the qi is complete in the true formula. Only when prior merits manifest verification at every stage may one dwell in a chamber of purity to enter the realm of the subtle and formless. There, one inwardly observes and recognizes the yang-spirit, then kindles the fire to subdue demons, burning the body to gather qi. The true qi ascends to the celestial palace, and within the shell, all is emptiness—nothing remains. Where to choose a secluded abode? Simply follow the practice of inward contemplation.

After the three bows are completed, sit upright without rising or adjusting posture, close the eyes, and still the mind. When stillness reaches its utmost and the primordial is invoked, the body seems suspended in space, the spirit and qi drifting freely, difficult to restrain. In silent inward contemplation, clarity shines unobscured: mountains and rivers appear resplendent, pavilions and towers faintly discernible. Purple qi and crimson light swirl in formation, auspicious simurghs and rainbow-feathered phoenixes sing with flute-like voices. Amidst such wondrous splendor—truly the delight of the alchemical crucible, a separate realm within the grotto-heaven—one roams carefree, oblivious to the burdens of the dusty world.

At this moment of true emptiness, the qi turns of itself, without need for method or adherence to time. If a blue-green qi emerges from the east, accompanied by the resonant strains of reed pipes and the procession of banners, chariots, and attendants—uncountable in number—before long, a crimson qi appears from the south, a white qi from the west, a black qi from the north, and a yellow qi from the center. The five qi converge to form radiant clouds, the air filled with joyous music and exuberant harmony. Golden lads and jade maidens escort one’s form, now riding a fiery dragon, now mounting a dark crane, now astride a rainbow phoenix, now bestriding a fierce tiger. Ascending into the void, rising from below, one traverses realms where towers and temples defy description, and divine officials and spirits surpass enumeration.

Arriving at another place, ten thousand rows of female musicians stand in array, officials ranked in order, like the court of an earthly emperor, with sages and worthies all in attendance. At this time, one remains unmoved by all around, ascending further until reaching a gate where guards stand solemn and inviolable. The officials and musicians linger behind, unable to follow, and as one passes through, a canopy veils the face. Descending once more, one returns to the former dwelling. Such ascent and descent occur countless times—this is the method of adjusting the spirit’s emergence from the shell.

With days of accumulated practice, one ascends directly to the celestial palace and descends back to the original place, moving freely without obstruction. The ascent begins from below, like climbing a seven-tiered pagoda or ascending a three-story crimson tower. At first, one ascends step by step, and upon reaching the seventh level, one must not look down, for the spirit, startled, clings to the body and refuses to depart. Only after reaching the summit may one leap with eyes closed, as if in dream or waking. A body exists outside the body, its form like an infant’s, skin fresh and radiant, spirit luminous. Looking back at the former shell, one sees nothing—only a heap of filth, a withered tree—shame and remorse arise, yet it cannot be abandoned at once for distant wandering.

For the spirit’s emergence is not yet perfected, and the sagely qi has not fully coalesced. One must re-enter the original body, mastering the art of coming and going until effortless. At first, one may wander but a step or two, then two or three *li*, and with accumulated practice, like a stalwart warrior, one may stretch an arm to traverse a thousand or ten thousand *li*. The spirit grows mighty, the form robust, and courage unshakable. Then one may entrust the mortal frame to the mountains and rivers, dwelling beyond the world’s responses, no longer mingling with the vulgar.

Thus, when merits are fulfilled, one receives the celestial writ, riding simurghs and phoenixes, straddling tigers and dragons, journeying east and west to enter the Purple Court. First, one meets the True Lord of the Grand Tenuity, then resides on the lower isles. To ascend to the grotto-heaven, one must transmit the Dao and accumulate merit among mortals. Receiving the celestial writ, one ascends to the grotto-heaven as a celestial immortal.

Few in ancient or modern times have succeeded in this practice, for many seek swift progress before merits are complete, or attempt transcendence through mere quiet sitting before verification is attained. Some, with lingering yin-spirits, emerge as ghost-immortals, unseen in form, wandering without destination, only to seize mortal shells and become human immortals. Others, unskilled in coming and going, lose the way back to their original body, their spirit adrift—this is the "sitting transformation" of Buddhist monks or the "corpse-liberation" of Daoist adepts.

One must choose a site and construct a chamber, far from all foul odors, putrid vapors, worldly noises, and the allure of women, lest they disturb the true qi or repulse the spirit. If one emerges and re-enters, enters and does not emerge, then form and spirit attain perfection, enduring as long as heaven and earth, undying through eons. If one emerges and does not re-enter, like a cicada shedding its husk, the spirit ascends to sageliness—transcending the mortal and shedding the vulgar to become a true immortal, dwelling beyond the dusty world on the isles of the Three Mountains.

The above is the secret of transcending the mortal to enter sageliness.
The Great Vehicle’s Three Gates pertain to celestial immortals.

chunks.original_text: 《玉书》曰：大道无形，视听不可以见闻。 大道无名，度数不可以筹算。 资道生形，因形立名。 名之大者，天地也。 天得乾道而积气，以覆於下。 地得坤道而托质，以载於上。 覆载之间，上下相去八万四千里，气质不能相交。 天以乾索於坤而还於地中，其阳负阴而上升。 地以坤索於乾而还於天中，其阴抱阳而下降。 一升一降运於道，所以天地长久。 《真原》曰：天地之间，亲乎上者为阳，自上而下四万二千里，乃曰阳位。 亲乎下者为阴，自下而上四万二千里，乃曰阴位。 既有形名，难逃度数。 且一岁者，四时、八节、二十四气、七十二候、三百六十日、四千三百二十辰。 十二辰为一日，五日为一候，三候为一气－，二气为一节，二节为一时，四时为一岁。 一岁以冬至节为始，是时也，地中阳升。 凡一气十五日，上升七千里。 三气为一节，一节四十五日，阳升共二万一千里。 二节为一时，一时九十日，阳升共四万二千里，正到天地之中，而阳合阴位，阴中阳半，其气为温，而时当春分之节也。 过此阳升而入阳位，方曰得气而升，亦如前四十五日立夏。 立夏之后，四十五日夏至。 夏至之节，阳升通前计八万四千里以到天，乃阳中有阳，其气热，积阳生阴，一阴生於二阳之中，自夏至之节为始，是时天中阴降。 凡一气十五日，下降七千里。 三气为一节，一节四十五日，阴降共二万一千里。 二节为一时，一时九十日，阴降共四万二千里，以到天地之中，而阴交阳位。 是时阳中阴半，其气为凉，而时当秋分之节也。 过此阴降而入阴位，方曰得气，而降亦如前四十五日立冬。 立冬之后，四十五日冬至。 冬至之节，阴降通前计八万四千里以到地，乃阴中有阴，其气寒。 积阴生阳，一阳生於二阴之中。 自冬至之后，一阳复升，如前运行不已，周而复始，不失於道。 冬至阳生，上升而还天。 夏至阴生，下降而还地。 夏至阳升到天而一阴来至，冬至阴降到地，而一阳来至，故曰：冬至。 阳升於上，过春分而入阳位以离阴位，阴降於下。 过秋分而入阴位，以离阳位。 故曰春分、秋分。 凡冬至阳升之后，自上而下，非无阴降也，所降之阴乃阳中之余阴，止於阳位中消散而已，纵使下降得位，与阳升相遇，其气绝矣。 凡夏至阴降之后，自下而上，非无阳升也，所升之阳乃阴中之余阳，止於阴位中消散而已，纵使上升得位，与阴降相遇，其气绝矣。 阴阳升降，上下不出於八万四千里，往来难逃於三百六十日，即温、凉、寒、热之四气而识阴阳，即阳升阴降之八节而知天地。 以天机测之，庶达大道之绪余。 若以口耳之学，较量於天地之道，安得筹算而知之乎。 比喻曰：道生万物，天地乃物中之大者，人为物中之灵者，别求於道，人同天地。 以心比天，以肾比地，肝为阳位，肺为阴位。 心肾相去八寸四分，其天地覆载之间，比也。 气比阳，而液比阴。 子午之时，比夏至、冬至之节。 卯酉之时，比春分、秋分之节。 以一日比一年，以日用八卦时比八节。 子时肾中气生，卯时气到肝。 肝为阳，其气旺阳升，以入阳位，其春分之比也。 午时气到心，积气生液，夏至阳升到天，而阴生之比也。 午时心中液生，酉时液到肺。

The *Jade Scripture* states: The Great Dao has no form, and cannot be perceived by sight or hearing. The Great Dao has no name, and cannot be measured by calculations or reckoning. It gives rise to form through the Dao, and names are established based on form. The greatest of names are Heaven and Earth. Heaven attains the Qian Dao and accumulates qi, covering all below. Earth attains the Kun Dao and supports substance, bearing all above. Between the covering and bearing, above and below are separated by eighty-four thousand li, and their qi and substance cannot interact. Heaven seeks Qian within Kun and returns to the center of Earth, its yang carrying yin upward. Earth seeks Kun within Qian and returns to the center of Heaven, its yin embracing yang downward. With each ascent and descent, they move through the Dao, and thus Heaven and Earth endure forever.

The *True Origin* states: Between Heaven and Earth, that which is close to above is yang; from above downward forty-two thousand li is called the yang position. That which is close to below is yin; from below upward forty-two thousand li is called the yin position. Once forms and names exist, they cannot escape measurement. Consider one year: four seasons, eight nodes, twenty-four qi, seventy-two hou, three hundred sixty days, and four thousand three hundred twenty periods. Twelve periods make one day, five days make one hou, three hou make one qi, two qi make one node, two nodes make one season, and four seasons make one year. The year begins with the Winter Solstice node, at which time yang ascends from within Earth. Each qi lasts fifteen days, ascending seven thousand li. Three qi make one node, one node forty-five days, with yang ascending a total of twenty-one thousand li. Two nodes make one season, one season ninety days, with yang ascending a total of forty-two thousand li, reaching precisely the center of Heaven and Earth, where yang meets the yin position. At this point, yang is half within yin, its qi becoming warm, corresponding to the Spring Equinox node. Beyond this, yang ascends into the yang position, now truly gaining qi and ascending, just as after forty-five days comes the Beginning of Summer. After the Beginning of Summer, forty-five days bring the Summer Solstice. At the Summer Solstice node, yang has ascended a total of eighty-four thousand li to reach Heaven, where yang is within yang, its qi hot. Accumulated yang generates yin, and one yin arises within two yang. Beginning with the Summer Solstice node, yin descends from within Heaven. Each qi lasts fifteen days, descending seven thousand li. Three qi make one node, one node forty-five days, with yin descending a total of twenty-one thousand li. Two nodes make one season, one season ninety days, with yin descending a total of forty-two thousand li to reach the center of Heaven and Earth, where yin meets the yang position. At this time, yin is half within yang, its qi becoming cool, corresponding to the Autumn Equinox node. Beyond this, yin descends into the yin position, now truly gaining qi and descending, just as after forty-five days comes the Beginning of Winter. After the Beginning of Winter, forty-five days bring the Winter Solstice. At the Winter Solstice node, yin has descended a total of eighty-four thousand li to reach Earth, where yin is within yin, its qi cold. Accumulated yin generates yang, and one yang arises within two yin. After the Winter Solstice, one yang ascends again, circulating endlessly as before, never deviating from the Dao.

At the Winter Solstice, yang is born, ascending to return to Heaven. At the Summer Solstice, yin is born, descending to return to Earth. When yang ascends to Heaven at the Summer Solstice, one yin arrives; when yin descends to Earth at the Winter Solstice, one yang arrives—hence the term "Winter Solstice." After yang ascends above, it passes the Spring Equinox to enter the yang position, departing from the yin position; yin descends below, passing the Autumn Equinox to enter the yin position, departing from the yang position—hence the terms "Spring Equinox" and "Autumn Equinox." After yang ascends at the Winter Solstice, from above downward, yin does not cease descending; the descending yin is merely the residual yin within yang, dissipating within the yang position. Even if it descends to its proper position and encounters ascending yang, its qi is exhausted. After yin descends at the Summer Solstice, from below upward, yang does not cease ascending; the ascending yang is merely the residual yang within yin, dissipating within the yin position. Even if it ascends to its proper position and encounters descending yin, its qi is exhausted. The ascent and descent of yin and yang, above and below, do not exceed eighty-four thousand li, and their coming and going cannot escape three hundred sixty days. Through the four qi of warmth, coolness, cold, and heat, one recognizes yin and yang; through the eight nodes of yang ascending and yin descending, one understands Heaven and Earth. Measuring this with the celestial mechanism, one may grasp the remnants of the Great Dao’s thread. If one relies on superficial learning to weigh the Dao of Heaven and Earth, how can calculations ever comprehend it?

For example: The Dao gives birth to the myriad things, and Heaven and Earth are the greatest among them. Humans are the most spiritually endowed among things, and when seeking the Dao separately, humans are akin to Heaven and Earth. The heart is likened to Heaven, the kidneys to Earth; the liver is the yang position, the lungs the yin position. The distance between heart and kidneys is eight cun and four fen, comparable to the space between Heaven’s covering and Earth’s bearing. Qi is likened to yang, and fluids to yin. The hours of *zi* and *wu* correspond to the Summer and Winter Solstice nodes; the hours of *mao* and *you* correspond to the Spring and Autumn Equinox nodes. At the *wu* hour, fluids are born within the heart; at the *you* hour, fluids reach the lungs.

That which naturally ascends from below does not exit; that which enters from without temporarily abides. The two qi converge, accumulating to generate the fluids of the five viscera. The more one returns to the origin, the greater the accumulation. With daily cultivation and persistent effort, results will appear in due course.

The *Essentials of the Dao* states: To meet the eldest son of yang, one must inhale more and exhale less. Let the children contend with one another, and in time, seek the true. This is the method of accumulating qi to generate fluids, and accumulating fluids to generate qi—matching and pairing qi and fluids to engender one another. In practice, no more than a year is needed; with concentrated effort, one achieves threefold progress in one. A hundred days as a term, and signs appear within ten. One gains appetite and dispels illness, clarity in head and eyes, lightness in heart and abdomen, strength with little fatigue. At times, the sound of wind and thunder arises within the abdomen—countless other signs cannot all be recorded.

Explanation: The "eldest son of yang" refers to *qian* seeking *xu* from *kun*, like qi ascending upward. The "son" is qi, rising from the kidneys. The "daughter" is fluid, descending from the heart. Their contention causes ascent and descent. By restraining qi, fluids are generated; when matched in balance, true water is naturally obtained after a time.

**Gathering and Dispersing Water and Fire, Second Scroll**

The *Golden Teachings* state: The Great Dao is lofty yet without superior—look up, and its summit cannot be seen. The Great Dao is lowly yet without inferior—look down, and its base cannot be seen. It has no beginning, so its origin cannot be perceived; it has no end, so its conclusion cannot be seen. Within the Great Dao, Heaven and Earth are born. Heaven and Earth possess the measures of high and low. Within Heaven and Earth, yin and yang exist, with their cycles of beginning and end. Observing upward and downward, one may fathom their mechanism. Contemplating beginning and end, calculating their measures, one may grasp their principles. From this, the Great Dao may be known.

The *True Origin* states: From the positions of Heaven and Earth above and below, one knows their height and depth. From the cycles of yin and yang’s beginning and end, one knows the sequence of Heaven’s Dao. Heaven and Earth do not depart from their measures, which conclude in one year. Yin and yang do not lose their proper order, dividing into the eight nodes. At the Winter Solstice, one yang is born; at the Spring Equinox, yang is half within yin. Beyond this, pure yang prevails, and yin is exhausted. At the Summer Solstice, yang reaches its extreme, and one yin is born—its ascent and descent follow as before. Though the cycles of above and below, beginning and end, do not fully encompass the Great Dao, they do not depart from its essence. To comprehend the Great Dao, one must model it upon Heaven and Earth and examine the proper order of yin and yang.

Analogy: The heart and kidneys are likened to Heaven and Earth; qi and fluids to yin and yang; one day to one year. The daily use of the *gen* trigram corresponds to the *Lichun* (Beginning of Spring) node in a year; the *qian* trigram to the *Lidong* (Beginning of Winter) node. Within Heaven and Earth, that which is closer to below is yin. From below upward, forty-two thousand *li* is called the yin position. At the Winter Solstice, yang is born and ascends; at the time of *Lichun*, yang rises within the yin position to twenty-one thousand *li*—this is yang’s struggle to overcome yin. Within Heaven and Earth, that which is closer to above is yang. From above downward, forty-two thousand *li* is called the yang position. At the Summer Solstice, yin is born and descends; at the time of *Lidong*, yin descends, departing sixty-three thousand *li* from Heaven and twenty-one thousand *li* from Earth—this is yin attaining its position and yang being cut off.

Within a year, *Lichun* corresponds to the *gen* trigram in a day’s hours. Kidney qi transmits downward to the bladder, weak and struggling to ascend within fluids. Within a year, *Lidong* corresponds to the *qian* trigram in a day’s hours. Heart fluids descend, about to return to the origin and re-enter the kidneys—this is the time of yin’s flourishing and yang’s severance.

The cause of human illness lies in the disharmony of yin and yang, with yang weak and yin excessive—thus, illness is common. The *True Formula* states: At *Lichun*, yang ascends from below; before long, yang is half within yin. At the *gen* trigram, qi is faint in the *chou* and *yin* hours. At *Lidong*, yin descends from above; before long, yin is half within yang. At the *qian* trigram, qi scatters in the *xu* and *hai* hours. Such is the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Yet humans, when qi is faint at the *gen* trigram, do not know the means to nurture qi; when qi scatters at the *qian* trigram, do not understand the principle of gathering qi. Day and night, the six desires and seven emotions dissipate primordial yang, causing true qi to weaken and scatter, true fluids to fail to generate. Thus, one cannot attain the longevity of Heaven and Earth—this is the reason.

Therefore, the ancients practiced *zhun* in the morning and *meng* in the evening, employing two trigrams daily to achieve long life in the world. *Zhun* in the morning takes the meaning of one yang coiled and unextended. For oneself, one nurtures and extends it, preventing dissipation.

chunks.original_text: 暮蒙者，盖取童蒙求我以就明弃暗，乃阴间求阳之义，其在我者，昧而明之，勿以走失。 是以日出当用艮卦之时，以养元气，勿以利名动其心，勿以好恶介其意。 当披衣静坐，以养其气。 绝念忘情，微作导引。 手脚递互伸缩三五下，使四体之气齐生，内保元气上升以朝於心府。 或咽津一两口，搓摩头面三、二十次，呵出终夜壅聚恶浊之气。 久而色泽充美，肌肤光润。 艮卦养元气。 又於日入用乾卦之时，以聚元气。 当入室静坐咽气，搐外肾。 咽气者，是纳心火於下。 搐外肾者，是收膀胱之气於内。 乾卦聚元气。 上下相合肾气之火，三火聚而为一，以补暖下田。 无液则聚气生液，有液则炼液生气，名曰聚火，又曰太一含真气也。 早朝咽津摩面，手足递互伸缩，名曰散火，又名曰小炼形也。 《道要》曰：花残叶落深秋，杨妃懒上危楼。 欲得君民和会，当时宴罢频收。 此纳心气而收膀胱气，不令耗散而相合肾气，以接坎卦气，海中新生之气也。 必以交立冬为首，见验方止。 行持不过一年，夺功以一并三，百日为期，旬日见验。 容颜光泽而肌肤充悦，下田温暖，小便减省，四体轻健而精神清爽，痼疾宿病尽皆消除。 如惜岁月，不倦行持，只於匹配阴阳功内稍似见验，叙入此功，日用添入艮卦，略行此法。 乾卦三元用事，应验方止。 三元乾、艮、震也。
