Thus, at sunrise, when the *gen* trigram governs, one nurtures primordial qi. Do not let profit or fame stir the heart, nor let likes and dislikes disturb the mind. Instead, don a robe and sit in stillness to cultivate qi. Banish thoughts and forget emotions, gently performing *daoyin*. Alternately stretch and contract the hands and feet three to five times, so that the qi of the four limbs arises evenly, inwardly preserving primordial qi to ascend and gather at the heart’s palace. One may swallow saliva once or twice and rub the head and face twenty to thirty times, exhaling the foul, stagnant qi accumulated through the night. With time, one’s complexion will glow with radiance, and the skin will become lustrous.

The *gen* trigram nurtures primordial qi. Furthermore, at sunset, when the *qian* trigram governs, one gathers primordial qi. Enter a chamber and sit in stillness, swallowing qi and contracting the external kidneys. Swallowing qi draws the heart’s fire downward. Contracting the external kidneys gathers the bladder’s qi inward. The *qian* trigram gathers primordial qi. When the upper and lower kidney fires unite, the three fires merge into one, warming and replenishing the lower elixir field. Without fluids, one gathers qi to generate fluids; with fluids, one refines them to produce qi. This is called "gathering fire" or "the Supreme Unity containing true qi."

In the early morning, swallowing saliva, rubbing the face, and alternately stretching the hands and feet is called "dispersing fire" or "minor refinement of form." As the *Daoist Essentials* states:

> The consort grows weary of ascending the high tower.
> To harmonize ruler and people,
> One must frequently gather after the feast.

This means drawing in the heart’s qi and gathering the bladder’s qi, preventing dissipation so they may unite with kidney qi to receive the qi of the *kan* trigram—the newly arisen qi from the sea. One must begin at the Winter Commencement solar term and continue until results appear. The practice should not exceed a year; the work of one merges into three, with a hundred days as the period and verification appearing in ten. The complexion will grow luminous, the skin full and joyful, the lower elixir field warm, urination reduced, the four limbs light and strong, the spirit clear and refreshed, and chronic illnesses entirely dissolved.

chunks.original_text: 解曰：花残叶落深秋者，如人气弱日暮之时，阳气散而不升，故曰懒上危楼。 楼者，重楼也。 心为君火，膀胱民火，咽气搐外肾，故心与外肾气聚而为一，故曰和会。 宴乃咽也，收乃搐也。 早辰功不绝者，此法为主本也。 交媾龙虎第三 《金诰》曰：太元初判而有太始，太始之中而有太无，太无之中而有太虚，太虚之中而有太空，太空之中而有太质。 太质者，天地也。 天地清浊，其质如卵而玄黄之色，乃太空之中一物而已。 阳升到天太极而生阴，以窈冥抱阳而下降。 阴降到地太极而生阳，以恍惚负阴而上升。 一升一降，阴降阳升，与天地行道而万物生成也。 《真原》曰：天如覆盆，阳到难升。 地如盘石，阴到难入。 冬至而地中阳升，夏至到天，其阳太极而生阴。 所以阴生者，以阳自阴中来而起於地，恍恍惚惚，气中有水，其水无形，夏至到天成水，是曰阳太极而阴生也。 夏至而天中阴降，冬至到地，其阴太极而阳生。 所以阳生者，以阴自阳中来而出於天，杳杳冥冥，水中有气，其气无形，冬至到地，积水生气，是曰阴太极而阳生也。 比喻曰：以身外比太空，以心肾比天地，以气液比阴阳，以子午比冬夏。 子时乃曰坎卦，肾中气生。 午时乃曰离卦，气到心。 肾气与心气相合而太极生液，所以生液者，以气自肾中来，气中有真水，其水无形。 离卦到心，接着心气，则太极而生液者如此。 离卦心中液生、坎卦液到肾，液与肾水相合而太极，复生於气。 所以生气者，以液自心中来，掖中有真气，其气无形。 坎卦到肾，接着肾水，则太极而生气者如此。 可以比阳升阴降，至太极而相生。 所生之阴阳，阳中藏水，阴中藏气也。 《真诀》曰：肾中生气，气中有真水。 心中生液，液中有真气。 真水、真气乃真龙、真虎也。 阳到天而难升，太极生阴。 阴到地而难入，太极生阳。 天地之理如此。 惟人也，不得比天地者，六欲、七情感物丧志，而耗散元阳，走失真气。 当离卦肾气到心，神识内定，鼻息少入迟出，绵绵若存，而津满口勿吐勿咽，自然肾气与心气相合，太极生液。 以液与真水相合，真气恋液，真水恋气。 本不相合，盖液中有真气，气中有真水，互相交合相恋而下，名曰交姤龙虎。 若以火候无差，而抽添合宜，三百日养就真胎而成大药，炼质焚身，朝元超脱之本也。 《道要》曰：一气初回元运，真阳欲到离宫，捉取真龙真虎，玉池春水溶溶。 此恐泄元气而走真水於身外也。 气散难生液，液少而无真气。 气、水不交，安成大药。 当此年中用月，以冬至为始，日中用时，以离卦为期。 或以晚年奉道，根源不固，自度虚损而气不足之后，十年之损，一年用功补之，名曰采补还丹。 补之过数，止行此法，名曰水火既济。 可以延年益寿，乃曰人仙。 功验不可备纪。 若补数足而口生甘津，心境自除，情欲不动，百骸无病，而神光暗中自见双目，时若惊电。 以冬至日为始节，用法三百日胎仙具。 解曰：在外午时为离宫，太阳为真阳。 在人心为离宫，元阳为真龙也，真虎乃肾中之水也。 真龙心液中之气，口为玉池，津为春水。 烧炼丹药第四 《金诰》曰：天地者，大道之形。 阴阳者，天地之道。 寒、热、温、凉，形中有气也。

Clouds, mist, rain, and dew—within qi there are images. Earth’s qi ascends, rising to become clouds and dispersing to become rain. Heaven’s qi descends, scattering into mist and condensing into dew. When accumulated yin exceeds, dew transforms into frost and then snow. When accumulated yang exceeds, mist becomes smoke, clouds, and rosy dawn. Within yin, yang lies concealed; if yang qi does not descend, it strikes and collides to generate thunder and lightning. Within yang, yin lies concealed; if yin qi does not congeal, it hardens to produce hail and graupel. When yin and yang fail to unite, they oppose each other to generate lightning. When yin and yang are mismatched, their chaotic union produces rainbows. Accumulated true yang forms spirits, which adorn the heavens as stars. Accumulated true yin forms shapes, which strengthen the earth as soil and stone. The greatest of stars are the sun and moon; the most precious of soil and stone are gold and jade. Yin and yang manifest in the visible forms of the sun and moon above, and gold and jade below.

*The True Origin* states: Yin cannot generate without yang; yang cannot complete without yin. Accumulated yang becomes spirit, adorning the heavens in grandeur—such are the sun and moon. The sun and moon are true yang that achieves completion through true yin. Accumulated yin forms shapes, strengthening the earth in preciousness—such are gold and jade. Gold and jade are true yin that attains generation through true yang.

Practice during the *xu* and *hai* hours: in the *Li* trigram, gather the medicine; in the *Qian* trigram, advance the fire. As an analogy: true yang corresponds to the true qi within heart fluid; true yin corresponds to the true water within kidney qi. True water cannot generate without true qi; true qi cannot complete without true water. When true water and true qi harmonize in the *Li* trigram—above the heart and below the lungs—they cling to each other like mother and child, or husband and wife in mutual affection.

From *Li* to *Dui*, when the *Dui* trigram’s yin flourishes and yang weakens, it resembles the moon’s waning crescent or gold and jade hidden in darkness, awaiting the dawn when their measure is fulfilled to shine anew. Gold and jade, refined by yang to generate yin, become treasures when qi is sufficient—this is achieved by advancing yang to fullness. The sun and moon renew their brightness when their measure is fulfilled and they receive the soul. This is analogous to advancing the fire in the *Qian* trigram, refining yang without declining flame, so that yang perpetually regenerates through incremental addition.

*The True Formula* states: When the Dragon and Tiger unite in the *Li* trigram, it is called "gathering the medicine." When the time arrives at the *Qian* trigram, qi and fluid prepare to return to their origin, generating above the bladder, below the spleen and stomach, before the kidneys, behind the navel, to the left of the liver, to the right of the lungs, to the right of the small intestine, and to the left of the large intestine. At this moment, spleen qi flourishes and lung qi thrives, while heart qi ceases and liver qi weakens. True qi, originally united with yang qi, now finds yang qi diminished and has nothing to cling to—practice at this time is laborious, yet the gathering and union must occur precisely then.

With spirit and awareness inwardly guarded, the breath flows gently through the nose. The abdomen subtly presses against the navel and kidneys; when the heat becomes too intense, slightly relax the pressure, gently restraining the navel. Before heat arises, tighten the restraint; as warmth grows, maintain steady pressure, allowing the mind to roam freely until it fills the cosmos—this is called "restraining the Yang Gate to refine the elixir." Thus, qi does not ascend but unites with true water, passing through the spleen palace and, with each breath, circulating into the life palace of the Yellow Court. As qi and fluid transform, they first become essence, then pearl, then mercury, then cinnabar, and finally gold—this is called the Golden Elixir. Its achievement is no small matter.

*The Essentials of the Dao* states: Gathering the medicine relies on the Jade Hare—heart qi is the medicine, and kidney water is the Jade Hare. Union must be facilitated by the Yellow Matron. When they meet in Yongzhou, the *Qian* trigram, perform a melody of the Yang Song. This practice aligns with daily cultivation for gathering the medicine.

For those seeking to restore vitality in later years, apply the method of "one supplement for every ten depletions"—this is called "refining mercury to supplement the cinnabar field." Once the supplement’s measure is fulfilled, cease daily practice.

Gather the medicine in the *Li* trigram and refine it in the *Qian* trigram, restraining the Yang Gate. In spring and winter, gather more and refine less—*Qian* requires one part effort, while *Li* demands twice as much. In autumn and summer, gather less and refine more—*Li* requires one part effort, while *Qian* demands twice as much. Adjust gathering and refining according to the seasonal flourishing of qi. With practice, results will manifest, extending years and abiding in the world as a Human Immortal.

If, after fulfilling the supplement’s measure, results are evident, advance with care and discipline. After one hundred days of gathering the medicine, its potency is complete. After two hundred days, the sacred embryo solidifies. After three hundred days, true qi is born, and the embryonic immortal is perfected.

Once the medicine’s potency is complete, advance the fire by increasing the measure—this is called "fire timing." After the sacred embryo solidifies, increase the fire timing to the measure of the Small Celestial Cycle. When the embryo is rounded and true qi is born, advance the fire timing—this is called the "Celestial Cycle fire timing."

Only by gathering the medicine through the union of Dragon and Tiger, and refining it by advancing the fire, does one enter the Dao. One must retreat to seclusion, focusing the mind on inner observation, so that inner visions do not leak out and outer distractions do not intrude—like a woman nurturing a fetus or a dragon tending its pearl. Even in eating, sleeping, speaking, or silence, one must move like an infant or a maiden in her chamber, ever cautious of loss or harm, never allowing the heart to stray from the Dao for even a moment.

A Commentary states: The medicine is the true qi within the heart; the hare is the true water within the kidneys; the Yellow Matron is the fluid within the spleen. They harmonize qi and water, entering the Yellow Court. Yongzhou is the *Qian* trigram, where one restrains the flanks and abdomen—also called restraining the Yang Gate.

Here concludes the four gates of the lesser vehicle, leading to Human Immortality. *Secret Transmission of the Orthodox Yang Immortal’s Numinous Treasure Complete Methods*, Volume One.

chunks.original_text: 秘传正阳真人灵宝毕法卷中 正阳真人锺离权云房着纯阳真人吕岩洞宾传 中乘长生不死法三门 肘后飞金晶第五 《金诰》曰：阴阳升降，不出天地之内。 日月运转，而在天地之外。 东西出没，以分昼夜。 南北往来，以定寒暑。 昼夜不息，积日为月，魄也。 岁之积月者，以其律中起吕，吕中起律也。 日月运行，以合天地之机，不离乾坤之数。 万物生成虽在於阴阳，而造化亦资於日月。 《真原》曰：天地之形，其状如卵。 六合於中，其圆如球。 日月出没，运行一天之上，一地之下。 上下东西，周行如飞轮。 东生西没，日行阳道。 西生东没，月行阴道。 一日之间而分昼夜。 冬至之后，日出自南而北。 夏至之后，日出自北而南。 冬之夜乃夏之日，夏之夜乃冬之日。 一年之间而定寒暑。 日月之状，方圆八百四十里。 四尺为一步，三百六十步为一里。 凡八刻二十分为一时，十二时为一日。 一月者，三十日，共三百六十时，计三千刻、一十八万分也。 且以阳行乾，其数用九。 阴行坤，其数用六。 魄中魂生，本自旦日。 盖其九不对六，故三日后月魄生魂。 凡一昼夜、一百刻、六千分，魂於魄中一进七十里。 六昼夜共进四百二十里，魄中魂半，乃曰上弦。 又六昼夜进四百二十里，通前共八百四十里，魄中魂全而阳满阴位，乃曰月望。 自十六日为始，魂中生魄，凡六昼夜共进四百二十里，而魂中魄半，乃曰下弦。 又六昼夜进四百二十里，通前共进八百四十里，而魂中魄全。 月中尚有余光者，盖六不尽九，故三日后月魄满宫，乃曰月晦。 月旦之后，六中起九。 月晦之前，九中起六。 数有未尽，而生后有期。 积日为月，积月为岁。 一岁以月言之，六律、六吕，以六起数，数尽六位。 六六三十六，阴之成数也，以日言之，五日一候，七十二候，八九之数。 至重九，以九起数，数尽六位。 六九五十四者，阳之成数也。 一六，一九，合而十五。 十五，气之数。 二十四气当八节之用，而见阴阳升降之宜。 一六、一九，以四为用，变为阳数二百一十六，阴之数一百四十四，计三百六十之数而足满周天。 比喻曰：阴阳升降在天地之内，比心肾、气液交合之法。 日月运转在天地之外，比肘后飞金精之事也。 日月交，比进火之法加减。 阳升阴降，无异於日月之魂魄。 日往月来，无异於心肾之气液。 冬至之后，日出乙位，日没庚位，昼四十刻，自南而北。 冬至之后，凡九日，东生西没，共进六十分至春分。 昼夜停停，而夏至为期，昼六十刻，日出甲位，日没辛位。 夏至之后，凡九日，自北而南，东生西没，共退六十分至秋分。 昼夜停停，而冬至为期，昼四十刻。 准前后，进自南而北，其数用九也。 月旦之后，三日魂生，魂生於魄。 六日两停，又六日魂全，其数用六也。 岁之夏至，月之十六日，乃日用离卦之法，乃人之午时也。 岁之冬至，月之旦，乃日用坎卦之法，乃人之子时也。 天地阴阳升降之宜、日月魂魄往来之理，尚以数推之，交合有序，运转无差，人之心肾气液、肝肺魂魄，日用虽有节次，年月岂无加减乎。 《真诀》曰：坎卦阳生，当正子时，非始非终，艮卦肾气交肝气。 未交之前，静室中披衣握固，正坐盘膝，蹲下腹肚，须臾升身前出胸，而微偃头於后。

The *Golden Proclamation* states: Yin and Yang ascend and descend, never beyond the bounds of Heaven and Earth. The sun and moon revolve, yet move outside Heaven and Earth. Their rising and setting in the east and west divide day and night; their coming and going in the south and north determine cold and heat. The sun and moon’s movements align with the mechanism of Heaven and Earth, never departing from the numbers of *Qian* and *Kun*. Though the generation of the myriad things depends on Yin and Yang, their transformation also relies on the sun and moon.

The *True Origin* states: The form of Heaven and Earth resembles an egg. The Six Harmonies within are round as a sphere. The sun and moon rise and set, revolving above one Heaven and below one Earth. Above and below, east and west, they circle like a flying wheel. The sun rises in the east and sets in the west, traveling the Yang path; the moon rises in the west and sets in the east, traveling the Yin path. Within a single day, they divide day and night. After the winter solstice, the sun rises from the south and moves north. After the summer solstice, the sun rises from the north and moves south. Winter’s night is summer’s day; summer’s night is winter’s day. Within a year, they determine cold and heat. The sun and moon each measure eight hundred and forty *li* in circumference. Four *chi* make one *bu*, and three hundred and sixty *bu* make one *li*. Eight *ke* and twenty *fen* make one *shi*, and twelve *shi* make one day. One month consists of thirty days, totaling three hundred and sixty *shi*, amounting to three thousand *ke* and one hundred and eighty thousand *fen*.

Since nine does not pair with six, three days later, the lunar phase gives birth to the spirit. In one day and night—one hundred *ke* and six thousand *fen*—the spirit advances seventy *li* within the lunar phase. Over six days and nights, it advances four hundred and twenty *li*, reaching half within the lunar phase—this is called the first quarter. After another six days and nights, advancing another four hundred and twenty *li*, totaling eight hundred and forty *li*, the spirit fully occupies the lunar phase, and Yang fills the Yin position—this is called the full moon.

Beginning on the sixteenth day, the spirit generates the lunar phase. Over six days and nights, advancing four hundred and twenty *li*, the lunar phase reaches half within the spirit—this is called the last quarter. After another six days and nights, advancing another four hundred and twenty *li*, totaling eight hundred and forty *li*, the lunar phase fully occupies the spirit. The remaining light in the moon exists because six does not exhaust nine; thus, three days later, the lunar phase fills the palace—this is called the dark moon.

After the new moon, nine arises from six. Before the dark moon, six arises from nine. Though the numbers are not yet exhausted, the next cycle begins in due course. Days accumulate into months, and months into years. Speaking of a year in terms of months, the six *lü* and six *lü* begin with six, exhausting the six positions. Six sixes make thirty-six—the completion number of Yin. Speaking of a year in terms of days, five days make one *hou*, and seventy-two *hou* make the number eight nines. One six and one nine, when applied fourfold, transform into the Yang number two hundred and sixteen and the Yin number one hundred and forty-four, totaling three hundred and sixty to complete the celestial cycle.

By analogy: The ascent and descent of Yin and Yang within Heaven and Earth resemble the method of harmonizing the heart and kidneys, *qi* and fluids. The revolution of the sun and moon outside Heaven and Earth resembles the practice of flying gold essence behind the elbow. The union of the sun and moon resembles the method of advancing and reducing fire. The ascent of Yang and descent of Yin are no different from the spirit and lunar phase of the sun and moon. The sun’s departure and moon’s arrival are no different from the *qi* and fluids of the heart and kidneys.

After the winter solstice, the sun rises in the *yi* position and sets in the *geng* position, with forty *ke* of daylight, moving from south to north. After the winter solstice, over nine days, the sun rises in the east and sets in the west, advancing sixty *fen* to the spring equinox. Day and night balance, with the summer solstice as the term, when daylight reaches sixty *ke*, the sun rises in the *jia* position and sets in the *xin* position. After the summer solstice, over nine days, the sun moves from north to south, rising in the east and setting in the west, retreating sixty *fen* to the autumn equinox. Day and night balance, with the winter solstice as the term, when daylight returns to forty *ke*. Following the previous pattern, advancing from south to north, the number uses nine.

After the new moon, on the third day, the spirit is born, arising from the lunar phase. On the sixth day, they balance; after another six days, the spirit is complete—the number uses six. At the winter solstice of the year and the new moon, one employs the method of the *Kan* trigram—this is the *zi* hour for humans. Though the proper ascent and descent of Yin and Yang in Heaven and Earth and the principles of the sun and moon’s spirit and lunar phase follow numerical order, their union is sequential and their revolution without error. How could the *qi* and fluids of the human heart and kidneys, the spirit and lunar phase of the liver and lungs, though following a daily rhythm, not require adjustment over months and years?

The *True Formula* states: When Yang is born in the *Kan* trigram, it corresponds to the true *zi* hour—neither beginning nor end. The *Gen* trigram governs the *qi* of the kidneys harmonizing with the *qi* of the liver. Then close the double gates of the *Jiaji* behind the spine, gently fan the elbows backward once or twice, and stretch the waist. If the fire does not rise, sit in stillness and inwardly observe; repeat the method until the fire ignites. Begin at the *chou* hour and continue until the end of *yin*. This is called *"Flying Golden Essence behind the Elbow"* or *"Drawing Lead"*, whereby kidney *qi* generates liver *qi*.

Moreover, the human spine has twenty-four vertebrae. The three lowest, from the bottom upward, correspond to the inner kidneys. The three highest, from the top downward, are called the *Heavenly Pillar*. Above the *Heavenly Pillar* lies the *Jade Capital*. Below the *Jade Capital* and above the *Weilü* point, where the inner kidneys align, are eighteen vertebrae—nine above and nine below—collectively called the *Double Gates*. After one hundred days of practice, the *qi* traverses all eighteen and enters the *Niwan*.

This must be performed during the *Kan* trigram’s true Yang hour. This is *"Flying Golden Essence behind the Elbow"*. The *Li* trigram governs the gathering of the elixir, the *Qian* trigram the stoking of the fire to refine it. After restraining the *Yang* gate for one hundred days, the *Golden Essence* flies into the brain. At one hundred days, the elixir’s power is complete. With a single thrust through the three gates, it ascends directly into the upper palace of *Niwan*.

Begin with the *Kan* trigram and conclude with the *Gen* trigram. When gathering the elixir under the *Li* trigram, no kidney *qi* unites with it; instead, liver *qi* naturally generates heart *qi*. The two *qi* become purely Yang, dissolving the eight Yin. Steaming the lungs, the lung fluid descends, enveloping the true *qi*. Daily, a grain of millet’s worth enters the *Yellow Court*—only then is it the material for the inner elixir. After one hundred days without error, the elixir’s power is complete.

When gathering the elixir under the *Li* trigram, follow the method precisely, inwardly observing with ever-greater refinement. For stoking the fire and restraining the *Yang* gate under the *Qian* trigram, begin with the *Dui* trigram and conclude with the *Qian* trigram. After another hundred days, *"Flying Golden Essence behind the Elbow"* proceeds from the *Kan* trigram to the *Zhen* trigram. When gathering the elixir under the *Li* trigram, the method remains unchanged, aligning with practice from the *Kun* to the *Qian* trigram. After three hundred days without error, the sacred embryo naturally solidifies. At three hundred days, the sacred embryo is firm.

The method of restraining the *Yang* gate begins with the *Kun* trigram and concludes with the *Qian* trigram. After another hundred days, the *Niwan* is fully replenished, and one reverts from old age to youth, no longer resembling ordinary people. The elixir is gathered, the embryo perfected, and true *qi* is born—round as a pellet, red as a tangerine—permanently settled in the *Dantian*, making one an immortal upon the earth.

After three hundred days, cease gathering the elixir under the *Li* trigram and restraining the *Yang* gate under the *Kun* trigram, then practice the *Jade Fluid Returning Elixir* method. Thus, only after the winter solstice does one begin the practice. After three hundred days, the embryo is complete, the *qi* is full, the inner elixir is achieved, and true *qi* is born. Only then is this the reversal of the Five Phases and the inversion of the Three Fields.

Before beginning the practice, first harmonize Yin and Yang to ensure *qi* and fluids generate one another, ceasing only when verification appears. Next, gather and disperse water and fire to solidify the root and ensure *qi* flows and fluids infuse, ceasing only when verification appears. Then unite the *Gou* Dragon and Tiger to refine the elixir, gathering and supplementing the returning elixir while forging lead and mercury, ceasing only when verification appears. When the count of *"Ten Losses and One Gain"* is complete and *qi* and fluids generate one another, cease only when verification appears.

The above practice is a lesser vehicle method, sufficient for prolonging life and extending years. Only after supplementation is complete and firmness verified may one select a month—specifically the winter solstice—and within that month, a day—specifically the *jiazi* day—and within that day, an hour—specifically the hours of the *Kan*, *Li*, and *Qian* trigrams—to begin.

For the first hundred days, proceed from *Kan* to *Gen* and from *Dui* to *Qian*. After two hundred days, proceed from *Kan* to *Zhen* and from *Kun* to *Qian*. For all such practice, one must be in a secluded chamber within a tranquil dwelling, far from women and girls, ensuring no sound of chickens or dogs reaches the ears, no foul odors enter the nose, no flavors pass the lips, and the seven emotions and six desires are extinguished. Regulate the quantity of food and drink, and maintain moderation in cold and heat. Even in waking and sleeping, guard against loss or damage. If practice is not diligent, the Dao will be difficult to achieve. After three hundred days, observe the results.

The *Dao Essentials* states: *"Sun and moon move together in the *Fu* trigram; at the *zi* hour, crouch and ascend for several days to open the gates. Greedily hasten to Yangzhou for the gathering; under the *Li* trigram, unite the *Gou*, and the six palaces’ fire fills the Golden Field of *Qian*.*
Explanation: *"Sun and moon move together in the *Fu* trigram"* refers to the time when a single Yang is born—in the day, the *zi* hour; in the year, the winter solstice. Restraining the *Yang* gate gathers the *qi*, and as the lungs are metal, the *qi* descends to the lower field below the buttocks—thus *"fire fills the Golden Field"*, meaning the *Qian* trigram’s restraint of the *Yang* gate gathers fire in the lower field.

*The Jade Book* states: True Yin and true Yang mutually engender and complete one another. That which appears above is accumulated *Yang* forming spirit. Within spirit lies form, clinging to heaven—these are the sun and moon. That which appears below is accumulated *Yin* forming shape. Within shape lies spirit, clinging to earth—these are gold and jade. The essence of gold and jade hides within mountains and rivers; their refined and radiant *qi* floats above, where the sun and moon exchange light. Plants and trees receive it, becoming auspicious omens; birds and beasts obtain it, becoming extraordinary species.

When *Yin* descends to earth, the Supreme Ultimate generates *Yang*; *Yang* is insufficient while *Yin* is surplus, hence accumulated *Yin* generates shape. Above, the sun and moon; below, gold and jade—true *Yang* possesses spirit, true *Yin* possesses shape. Their *qi* intermingles, shooting upward and downward, filling heaven and earth with light. The *qi* of gold and jade congealing in the void to become auspicious mist and propitious vapor is like refining form with *qi*. Whenever the *qi* of gold and jade surges into heaven, it rises with *Yang*. Whenever it enters the earth, it descends with *Yin*. Since it follows *Yin* and *Yang* in ascent and descent, there are four seasons in which the fluid can return to the cinnabar field. Refining form with *qi* adjusts by adding or subtracting a day according to the four seasons.

*The True Formula* states: Upon verifying the effects of gathering and supplementing, choose the month within the year, the day within the month, and the hour within the day. Diligently regulate practice, augmenting in accordance with the seasons. Only after completing the three hundred days does one proceed with the method of returning the elixir and refining form.

Having ceased the *Li* trigram, add the swallowing method to refine form.

In the three months of summer, when heart *qi* is flourishing and lung *qi* is weak, apply the swallowing method daily using the *Xun* trigram, filling the upper and lower tongue to the Jade Pool, swallowing the emptiness of both cheeks as the method. In the three months of autumn, when lung *qi* is flourishing and liver *qi* is weak, apply the swallowing method daily using the *Gen* trigram. chunks.original_text: 每四时季月之后十八日，咽法日用兑卦，仍与前咽法者并用之。 独於秋季，止用兑卦咽法，而罢艮卦之功。 凡以咽法，先依前法而咽之。 如牙齿玉池之间而津不生，但以舌满上下而闭玉池收两颊，以虚咽而为法止咽气，气中自有水也。 咽气如一年三十六次至四十九次。 为数，又次一年八十一次又一百八十一次。 为见验，乃玉液还丹之法。 行持不过三年，灌溉丹田，沐浴胎仙，而真气愈盛。 若不行此玉液还丹之法，而於三百日养就内丹，真气才生，艮卦飞金晶，一撞三关，上至泥丸，当行金液还丹之法。 自顶中前下金水一注，下还黄庭，变金成丹，名曰金丹。 行金液还丹，当於深密幽房，风、日凡人不到之处，烧香迭掌，盘膝坐，以体蹲而后升，才觉火起，正坐绝念忘情，内观的确艮卦飞金晶入顶，但略昂头偃项，放令颈下如火，方点头向前，低头曲项，退舌尖进后，以抵上腭，上有清冷之水，味若甘香，上彻顶门，下通百脉。 鼻中自闻一种真香，舌上亦有奇味，不漱而咽下，还黄庭，名曰金液还丹。 春、夏、秋、冬不拘时候，但於肘后飞金晶入脑之后，节次行此法，自艮至巽而已。 晚间勒阳关法，自兑至乾而已。 尺行此法谨节，胜及前方，可得成志意，止於炼形住世、长生不死而已，不能超脱也。 《道要》曰：识取五行根蒂，方知春夏秋冬，时饮琼浆数盏，醉归月殿遨游。 解曰：识取五行根蒂者，为到五行相生相克而用卦时不同，以行咽法，方知春夏秋冬改移有时侯也。 琼浆，玉液也。 月殿，是丹田。 醉，则咽多也。 东望扶桑未晓，后升前偃无休，骤马数游宇宙，长男只到杨州。 解曰：东望扶桑未晓者，日未出艮卦之时，后升飞金晶也。 前偃，玉液还丹。 骤马，起火玉液炼形也。 遨游宇宙，遍满四肢也。 长男，震卦。 只到杨州，离卦也。 玉液炼形，自震卦为始，至离卦方止也。 此采药三百日，数足胎圆，而飞金晶减一卦，勒阳关如旧。 罢采药，添入咽法。 咽法随四时而已，此系炼形法。 用卦候添入炼形，自震卦为始，离卦为期，不限年月日，见验方止。 身体光泽，神气秀媚，渐畏腥秽以冲己腹。 凡情、凡爱心境自除，真气将足而以常饱，所食不多而饮酒无量，尘骨巳更而变神识，步趋走马而行如飞，目如点漆，体若凝脂，绀发再生，皱脸重舒，老去永驻童颜，仰视百步而见秋毫，身体之间旧痕残靥自然消除，涕泪、涎、污亦不见有也。 圣丹生味，灵液透香，口鼻之间常有真香奇味，漱成凝酥，可以疗人疾病，遍体皆成白膏。 上件皆玉液还丹炼形之验也。 验既正，当谨节用功，依法随时而行后事。 金液还丹第七 《金诰》曰：积阳成神，神中有形，一生於日，日生於月。 积阴成形，形中有神，一生於金，金生於玉。 随阴阳而生没者，日月之光也。 因数生光，数本於乾坤。 随阴阳而升降者，金玉之气也。 因时起气，时本於天地。 《真原》曰：数行日月，数用六、九。 乾坤之数、金玉之气春夏上升，秋冬下降。 升降，天地之时。 金生於土，土生於石，石生於玉，见於成形而在下者如此。 日中金鸟，月中玉兔，日待月魄而光，见於成神而在上者如此。 比喻曰：日月比气也，肾气比月，而心气比日。

For all swallowing methods, first follow the preceding method. If saliva does not arise between the teeth and the Jade Pool, simply fill the upper and lower tongue, close the Jade Pool, gather both cheeks, and swallow the emptiness as the method—only the *qi* is swallowed, for within *qi* there is naturally water. The swallowing of *qi* should number thirty-six to forty-nine times in one year, then eighty-one times in the next year, and one hundred eighty-one times thereafter. This is the method for verifying the return of Jade Liquid Elixir. Practicing this for no more than three years will irrigate the Cinnabar Field, bathe the Embryonic Immortal, and cause true *qi* to flourish ever more.

If one does not practice this Jade Liquid Return Elixir method but instead nurtures the Internal Elixir for three hundred days, true *qi* will only just begin to arise. Then, using the *Gen* trigram’s Flying Golden Essence, strike through the Three Passes to ascend to the Mud Pill Palace. At that point, one must practice the Golden Liquid Return Elixir method: from the crown’s center, let the golden water descend in a single stream to return to the Yellow Court, where it transforms into gold and congeals into the Elixir, called the Golden Elixir.

When practicing the Golden Liquid Return Elixir, choose a secluded chamber where wind, sunlight, and ordinary people cannot reach. Burn incense, clasp the hands, sit cross-legged, and after settling the body, rise. As soon as the fire is felt, sit upright, extinguish all thoughts and emotions, and inwardly observe the *Gen* trigram’s Flying Golden Essence entering the crown. Slightly raise the head and tilt the neck back, allowing the fire to fill the throat. Then nod forward, lower the head, and curve the neck, retracting the tongue’s tip to press against the upper palate. There, cool and refreshing water will appear, its taste sweet and fragrant, ascending to the crown’s gate and circulating through the hundred meridians. A true fragrance will naturally arise in the nose, and an extraordinary flavor will linger on the tongue. Without rinsing, swallow it down to return to the Yellow Court—this is the Golden Liquid Return Elixir.

Regardless of spring, summer, autumn, or winter, after the Flying Golden Essence enters the brain following the *hou* method, proceed step by step with this practice, moving from *Gen* to *Xun*. At night, apply the Yang Barrier Restraining method, progressing from *Dui* to *Qian*. If one meticulously follows this method, it surpasses the previous techniques, enabling the fulfillment of one’s will. However, this only refines the form to abide in the world and attain longevity without death—it does not achieve liberation.

The *Essentials of the Dao* states: "Recognize the root and foundation of the Five Phases, and you will understand the seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter. Drink several cups of nectar, then wander drunkenly to the Moon Palace."

"Gazing eastward at Fusang before dawn, rising behind and reclining ahead without rest, a galloping steed roams the cosmos, while the eldest son only reaches Yangzhou."

The explanation: "Gazing eastward at Fusang before dawn" refers to the time before sunrise, when the *Gen* trigram’s Flying Golden Essence rises. "Reclining ahead" is the Jade Liquid Return Elixir. "Galloping steed" is the firing of Jade Liquid to refine the form. "Roaming the cosmos" means filling the four limbs. "Eldest son" is the *Zhen* trigram. "Only reaches Yangzhou" is the *Li* trigram. Refining the form with Jade Liquid begins with the *Zhen* trigram and ends with the *Li* trigram.

After gathering the medicine for three hundred days, the embryo is complete, and the Flying Golden Essence reduces by one trigram, while the Yang Barrier Restraining remains unchanged. Cease gathering the medicine and incorporate the swallowing method, which follows the four seasons. This pertains to the method of refining the form. When adding the trigram timing to refine the form, begin with the *Zhen* trigram and conclude with the *Li* trigram, without limiting the years, months, or days—only stopping upon verification.

The body will become radiant, the spirit refined and graceful, and one will gradually develop an aversion to foul odors that offend the abdomen. Worldly emotions and attachments will naturally dissolve, true *qi* will become abundant and constantly satiating, food intake will lessen while wine capacity increases, the mortal frame will transform into spiritual awareness, and movement will be as swift as a galloping horse. The eyes will be as dark as lacquer, the body as smooth as congealed fat, white hair will turn black again, wrinkled skin will smooth out, and old age will permanently retain a youthful appearance. One will see autumn down at a hundred paces, old scars and blemishes will naturally fade, and tears, saliva, and filth will no longer appear. The Sacred Elixir will generate flavor, the numinous liquid will exude fragrance, and true fragrance and extraordinary taste will constantly linger in the mouth and nose. The saliva will congeal into refined butter, capable of curing illnesses, and the entire body will become white cream. All these are verifications of refining the form with the Jade Liquid Return Elixir.

Once verification is confirmed, one must diligently follow the method and proceed with subsequent practices according to the season.

The *Golden Edict* states: "Accumulated yang forms spirit, and within spirit there is form—once born from the sun, the sun is born from the moon. Accumulated yin forms the body, and within the body there is spirit—once born from metal, metal is born from jade. That which follows yin and yang in arising and vanishing is the light of the sun and moon, for light arises from number, and number originates from *Qian* and *Kun*. That which follows yin and yang in ascending and descending is the *qi* of metal and jade, for *qi* arises from time, and time originates from heaven and earth."

The *True Origin* states: "The numbers of the sun and moon employ six and nine. The numbers of *Qian* and *Kun*, the *qi* of metal and jade, ascend in spring and summer and descend in autumn and winter. Ascending and descending are the seasons of heaven and earth. Metal is born from earth, earth from stone, stone from jade—this is how form manifests below. The golden crow in the sun, the jade hare in the moon, the sun awaits the moon’s essence to shine—this is how spirit manifests above."

The analogy: "The sun and moon correspond to *qi*; kidney *qi* corresponds to the moon, and heart *qi* corresponds to the sun."

chunks.original_text: 金玉比液也，肾液比金，而心液比玉。 所谓玉液者，本自肾气上升而到於心，以合心气，二气相交而过重楼，闭口不出而津满玉池，咽之而曰玉液还丹，升之而曰玉液炼形。 是液本自肾中来，而生於心。 亦比土中生石，石中生玉之说也。 所谓金液者，肾气合心气而不上升，熏蒸於肺，肺为华盖，下罩二气，即日而取肺液，在下田自尾闾穴升之，乃曰飞金晶入脑中，以补泥丸。 补足自上复下降，而入下田，乃曰金液还丹。 既还下田，复升遍满四体前后上升，乃曰金液炼形。 是亦金生於土之说也。 凡欲炼形飞金晶者，当在净室中，切禁风、日，遥焚香密启： 三清上圣，臣所愿长生在世，传行大道，演化告人，当先自行炼形之法，欲得不畏寒暑，绝啖谷食，逃於阴阳之外。 咒毕乃咽之。 《真诀》曰：背后尾闾穴曰下关，夹脊曰中关，脑下曰上关。 始飞金晶以通三关，肾比地，心比天，上到顶以比九天。 玉液炼形，自心至顶，以通九天。 三百日咽，大药就，胎仙圆，而真气生。 前起则行玉液炼形之旧道，后起则行飞金晶之旧道。 金晶玉液，行功见验，自坎卦为始，后起一升入顶，以双手微闭双耳内观，如法微咽於津。 乃以舌抵定牙关，下闭玉池，以待上腭之津，下而方咽，咽毕复起，至艮卦为期。 春冬两起一咽，秋夏五起一咽。 凡一咽数，秋夏不过五十数，春冬不过百数。 自后咽罢升身前起，以满头面、四肢、手指气盛方止。 再起再升，至离卦为期。 凡此后起咽津，乃曰金液还丹。 还丹之后而复前起，乃曰金液炼形。 自艮卦之后炼形，至离卦方止。 兑卦勒阳关，至乾卦方止。 以后起到顶，自上而下，号曰金液还丹。 金丹之气，前起自下而上，曰金液炼形形。 显琪树金花，若以金液还丹未到下元，而前后俱起，乃曰火起焚身，此是金液还丹炼形既，前后俱起，兼了焚身。 凡行此等，切须谨节苦志而无懈怠，以见验为度也。 《道要》曰：起后终宵闭耳，随时对饮金波，宴到青州方住，日西又听阳歌。 解曰：起后终宵闭耳者，为行金液还丹须是肘后飞金晶，一撞三关，其气才起，急须双手闭耳。 耳是肾波之门，恐泄肾气於外而不入脑中也。 随时对饮金波者，既觉气入脑中。 即便依前法点头曲项，退舌尖，近拄上腭，清甘之水有奇异是验，甘若蜜也。 当艮卦飞金晶一咽，至震卦方止。 青州，乃震卦也。 日西，兑卦也。 又听阳歌者，自兑卦勒阳关，直至乾卦，日用离卦，不必采药也。 饮罢终宵火起，前升后举焚身，虽是不拘年月，日中自有乾坤。 解曰：此一诀是金液炼形之法也。 饮罢终宵火起者，是依前法金液还丹，而艮卦炼形是起火也。 前升后举，飞金晶起火也。 凡玉液炼形之时，先后起金晶入顶，次还丹而复前升之以炼形，是金液炼形之法不同也。 当其飞金晶而起火入顶，便前起而炼形。 前后俱起名曰焚身。 火而行还丹，须依四时加减之数。 所行此法，不拘年月日时，但以谨节专一，幽居绝迹可也。 日中自有乾坤，盖午前烧乾，午后烧坤。 人以前后言之，肚腹为坤，而背后为乾。 午前烧乾者，为肘后飞金晶，前起炼形也。 午后烧坤者，自兑卦勒阳关，至乾卦方止故也。 此须於玉液还丹炼形见验正当，方以谨节幽居，焚香而行此法。

The so-called *jade essence* originates from kidney *qi*, ascending to the heart to merge with heart *qi*. When the two *qi* intersect and pass the *Double Towers*, the mouth is sealed, and the *saliva* fills the *Jade Pool*. Swallowing it is called *jade essence returning cinnabar*; refining it upward is called *jade essence refining form*. This essence arises from the kidneys yet is born in the heart—analogous to stone emerging from earth and jade from stone.

The so-called *golden essence* occurs when kidney *qi* merges with heart *qi* without ascending, instead steaming the lungs. The lungs, as the *flowery canopy*, enshroud the two *qi*. Drawing lung essence at dawn, one guides it from the *Lower Field* upward through the *Weilü* cavity, calling it *flying golden radiance into the brain* to replenish the *Mud Pill Palace*. Once replenished, it descends from above back to the *Lower Field*, called *golden essence returning cinnabar*. After returning to the *Lower Field*, it ascends again, suffusing the four limbs and rising front and back—this is *golden essence refining form*, also illustrating how metal is born from earth.

For those refining form and flying golden radiance, one must be in a pure chamber, strictly avoiding wind and sunlight. From afar, burn incense and silently invoke: *"Three Pure Ones and Supreme Sages, may your servant dwell long in the world, transmit the Great Dao, and teach others. The kidneys correspond to earth, the heart to heaven, ascending to the crown to mirror the *Nine Heavens*. Jade essence refining form rises from the heart to the crown, connecting the *Nine Heavens*. Rising forward follows the old path of jade essence refining form; rising backward follows the old path of flying golden radiance. As prescribed, gently swallow the saliva. Press the tongue against the teeth, seal the *Jade Pool*, and await the essence from the upper palate before swallowing. After swallowing, rise again, concluding at the *Gen* trigram. In spring and winter, swallow once per two risings; in autumn and summer, swallow once per five risings. Each swallow’s count should not exceed fifty in autumn and summer, nor one hundred in spring and winter. After swallowing, rise forward to suffuse the head, face, limbs, and fingers until the *qi* is abundant. Rise again, concluding at the *Li* trigram. *The Dao Essentials* states: *"After rising, close the ears all night, drink the golden waves in due time, and feast until reaching Qingzhou before stopping. chunks.original_text: 《金诰》曰：一气初判，大道有形而列二仪。 二仪定位，大道有名而分五帝。 五帝异地而各守一方，五方异气而各守一子。 青帝之子甲乙受之天真木德之九气。 赤帝之子丙丁，受之天真火德之三气。 白帝之子庚辛，受之天真金德之七气。 黑帝之子壬癸，受之天真水德之五气。 黄帝之子戊己，受之天真土德之一气。 自一生真一，真一因土出，故万物生成在土，五行生成在一，真元之道，皆一气生也。 《玉书箓》曰：一、三、五、七、九，道之分而有数。 金、木、水、火、土，道之变而有象。 东、西、南、北、中，道之列而有位。 青、白、赤、黄、黑，道之散而有质。 数归於无数，象反於无象，位至於无位，质还於无质。 欲道之无数，不分之则无数矣。 欲道之无象，不变之则无象矣。 欲道之无位，不列之则无位矣。 欲道之无质，不能之则无质矣。 无数则道之源也，无象则道之本也，无位则道之真也，无质则道之妙也。 《真原》曰：道原既判，降本流末，悟其真者，因真修真，内真而外真自应矣。 识其妙者，因妙得妙，内妙而外妙自应矣。 天地得道之真，其真未应，故未兔乎有位。 天地得道之妙，其妙未应，故未兔乎有质。 有质则有象可求，有位则有数可推。 天地之间、万物之内，最贵惟人。 即天地之有象可求，故知其质气与水也。 即天地之有数可推，故知其位远与近也。 审乎如是，而道亦不远於人也。 比喻曰：天地有五帝，而比人之有五脏也。 青帝甲乙木，甲为阳，乙为阴，比肝之气与液也。 黑帝壬癸水，壬为阳，癸为阴，比肾之气与液也。 黄帝戊己土，戊为阳，己为阴，比脾之气与液也。 赤帝丙丁火，丙为阳，丁为阴，比心之气与液也。 白帝庚辛金，庚为阳，辛为阴。 比肺之气与液也。 凡春夏秋冬之时不同，而心肺肝肾之旺有月。 《真诀》曰：凡春三月，肝气旺。 肝旺者，父母真气随天度运而在肝。 若遇木日，甲乙救土於辰戌丑未之时，依时起火炼脾气。 余日兑卦时损金以耗肺气，是时不可下功也。 坎卦时依法起火炼肾气。 震卦时入室多入少出息住为上，久闭次之数至一千息为度，当时内观如法，一意冥心闭目，青色自见，渐渐升身，以入泥丸，自寅至辰，以满震卦。 一千息以上尤佳，如息急渐微，出息而息住，不须连成。 凡夏三月，心气旺。 心旺者，以父母之真气随天度运而在心。 若遇火日，丙丁救金，於兑卦时依法起火炼肺气，余日坎卦时损水以耗肾气，是时不可下功也。 震卦时依法起火炼肝气。 离卦时入室依前行持定息，赤色自见，渐渐升身，以入泥丸，自巳至未，以满离卦。 一千息以上尤佳，其说如前。 凡秋三月，肺气旺。 肺旺者，以父母真气随天度运而在肺。 若遇金日，庚辛救木，於震卦时依法起火炼肝气。 余日离卦损火以耗心气，是时不可下功也。 巽卦时依法起火炼脾气。 兑卦时入室依前行持，白色自见，渐渐升身，以入泥丸，自申至戌以满兑卦。 凡冬三月，肾气旺。 肾旺者，父母之真气随天度运而在肾。 若遇水日，壬癸救火，於离卦时依法起火炼心气。 余日辰、戌、丑、未时损土以耗脾气，是时不可下功也。 兑卦时依法起火炼肺气。 坎卦时入室依前行持，黑色自见，渐渐升身，以入泥丸，自亥至丑以满坎圭

At the primal division of the singular *qi*, the Great Dao took form and arrayed the Two Modes. **The Jade Book of Registers** states:
One, three, five, seven, nine—these are the Dao’s divisions manifesting as numbers. Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—these are the Dao’s transformations manifesting as images. East, West, South, North, Center—these are the Dao’s arrangements manifesting as positions. Azure, white, vermilion, yellow, black—these are the Dao’s dispersals manifesting as substances. chunks.original_text: 《金诰》曰：大道本乎无体，寓於气也。 其大无外，无物可容。 大道本乎无用，运於物也。 其深莫测，无理可究。 以体言道，道之始有内外之辨。 以用言道，道之始有观见之基。 观乎内而不观乎外，外无不究而内得明。 观乎神而不观乎形，形无不备而神得见矣。 《真原》曰：以一心观万物，万物不谓之有余。 以万物挠一气，一气不谓之不足。 一气归诸心，心不可为物之所夺。 一心运一气，气不可为法之所役。 心源清彻，一照万破，亦不知有物也。 气战刚强，万感一息，亦不知有法也。 物物无物，以还本来之象。 法法无法，乃全自得之真矣。 比喻曰：以象生形，以形立名。 有名则推其数，有数则得其理。 比者之论。 盖高上虚无，无物可喻。 所可比者，如人之修炼，节序无差，成就有次。 冲和之气凝而不散，至虚真性恬淡无为，神合乎道，归於自然。 当此之际，以无心为心。 如何谓之应物，以无物为物。 如何谓之用法，真乐熙熙不知己之有身。 渐入无为之道，以入希夷之域，斯为入圣超凡之客。 《真诀》曰：此法合道，有如常说存想之理，又如禅僧入定之时。 当择福地置室，跪礼焚香，正坐盘膝，散发披衣，握固存神，冥心闭目。 午时前微以升身起火炼气，午后微以敛身聚火烧丹。 不拘昼夜，神清气和，自然喜坐。 坐中或闻声莫听，见境勿认，物境自散。 若认物境，转加魔军不退，急急前以身微敛，敛而伸腰，后以胸微偃，偃不伸腰，少待前后火起，高升其身勿动，名曰焚身。 火起魔军自散於躯外，阴邪不入於壳中，如此三两次已。 当想遍天地之间皆是炎炎之火，毕清凉，了无一物。 但见车马歌舞轩盖绮罗、富贵繁华、人物欢娱，成队成行，五色云升，如登天界。 及到彼中，又见楼台耸翠，院宇徘徊，珠珍金玉满地不收，花果池亭莫知其数。 须臾异香四起，妓乐之音嘈嘈杂杂，宾朋满坐，水陆俱陈，且笑且语，共贺太平，珍玩之物互相献受。 当此之际，虽然不是阴鬼魔军，亦不得认为好事。 盖修真之人弃绝外事，甘受寂寞，或潜迹江湖之地，或遁身隐僻之隅，绝念忘情，举动自戒，久受劬劳而历潇洒。 一旦功成法立，遍见如此繁华，又不谓是阴魔，将谓实到天宫。 殊不知脱凡胎在顶中自己天宫之内，因而贪恋，认为实境，不用超脱之法，止於身中阳神不出，而胎仙不化，乃曰出昏衢之上，为陆地神仙而可，长生不死而已，不能脱质升仙而归三岛以作人仙子也。 当此可惜，学人自当虑超脱虽难，不可不行也。 《道要》曰：不无尽法，已灭省故也。 超脱第十 《金诰》曰：道本无也，以言有者，非道也。 道本虚也，以言实者，非道也。 既为无体，则问应俱不能矣。 既为无相，则视听俱不能矣。 以玄微为道，玄微亦不离问苔之累。 以希夷为道，亦未免为视听之累。 希夷玄微尚未为道，则道亦不知其所以然也。 《玉书》曰：其来有始而不知大道之始，何也。 其去有尽而不知大道之终，何也。 高高之上虽有上，不知大道之上无有穷也。 深深之下虽有下，不知大道之下无有极也。 杳冥莫测名曰道，随物所得而列等殊。 无为之道，莫能穷究也。 《真诀》曰：超者，是超出凡躯而入圣品。 脱者，是脱去俗胎而为仙子。

The *Golden Proclamation* states: The Great Dao is fundamentally formless, residing within *qi*. Its vastness knows no bounds, and no thing can contain it. The Great Dao is fundamentally functionless, yet operates through things. Its depth is unfathomable, and no principle can exhaust it. Speaking of the Dao in terms of its body, it then begins to have distinctions of inner and outer. Speaking of the Dao in terms of its function, it then begins to have a basis for observation and perception. Observe inwardly and not outwardly, and though nothing external remains unexamined, clarity is attained within. Observe the spirit and not the form, and though no form is left unprepared, the spirit becomes visible.

The *True Origin* states: With one mind observe the myriad things, and the myriad things are not said to be in excess. With the myriad things disturbing the one *qi*, the one *qi* is not said to be insufficient. When the one *qi* returns to the mind, the mind cannot be seized by things. When the one mind moves the one *qi*, the *qi* cannot be enslaved by methods. When the source of the mind is clear and penetrating, one illumination shatters ten thousand delusions, and one is unaware of the existence of things. When *qi* wages a fierce struggle, ten thousand sensations are stilled in a single breath, and one is unaware of the existence of methods. Things are no-things, returning to the original image. Methods are no-methods, thereby fulfilling the true nature of self-attainment.

For analogy: form arises from image, and names are established from form. With names, one infers their numbers; with numbers, one grasps their principles. Such is the discourse of analogy. Yet the supreme and void Dao transcends all things, and nothing can serve as a comparison. What can be likened is this: as in human cultivation, the seasons and sequences are without error, and accomplishments follow in order. The harmonious *qi* congeals without dispersing; the true nature, utterly serene, is without action. The spirit merges with the Dao and returns to spontaneity. At this juncture, take non-mind as mind. How then is one to respond to things? Take non-things as things. How then is one to employ methods? In true joy, one is blissfully unaware of having a body. Gradually entering the Dao of non-action, one reaches the realm of the subtle and imperceptible, becoming a guest who has entered sagehood and transcended the mundane.

The *True Formula* states: This method accords with the Dao, resembling the principle of visualization often discussed, or like the moment when Chan monks enter samadhi. Choose an auspicious site to establish a chamber. Kneel, pay respects, burn incense, sit upright with legs crossed, let the hair down, loosen the robes, clench the fists to retain spirit, empty the mind, and close the eyes. Before noon, slightly raise the body to kindle the fire and refine *qi*. After noon, slightly gather the body to concentrate the fire and burn the elixir. Regardless of day or night, when the spirit is clear and *qi* harmonious, one naturally delights in sitting. During sitting, if sounds are heard, do not listen; if visions appear, do not acknowledge them, and the illusory realms will disperse of themselves. If one acknowledges the illusory realms, demonic forces will intensify and not retreat. Immediately, slightly gather the body, then stretch the waist; afterward, slightly recline the chest without stretching the waist. Wait briefly until the fire rises before and behind, then raise the body without moving—this is called "firing the body." When the fire rises, demonic forces scatter beyond the body, and yin evil does not enter the shell. Repeat this two or three times. Then visualize all between heaven and earth as a raging fire, entirely cool and devoid of things. Only then may one see carriages, horses, singing, dancing, canopies, silks, wealth, splendor, and joyous multitudes—processions in rows, five-colored clouds ascending, as if ascending to the celestial realms. Upon arriving there, one sees towering pavilions of jade green, courtyards stretching endlessly, pearls, jewels, gold, and jade scattered ungathered upon the ground, flowers, fruits, ponds, and pavilions beyond count. Suddenly, exotic fragrances arise on all sides, and the sounds of music and revelry fill the air. Guests and friends sit in full assembly, with delicacies of land and sea laid out. Laughter and conversation abound, celebrating great peace, and precious objects are exchanged as gifts. At this moment, though these are not yin ghosts or demonic forces, one must not regard them as auspicious. The true cultivator renounces external affairs, willingly endures solitude, conceals traces in rivers and lakes, or withdraws to secluded corners, cutting off thoughts and forgetting emotions, ever vigilant in conduct, enduring hardship and enjoying freedom. Once the work is accomplished and the method established, one may suddenly witness such splendor. Though not considering it a demonic illusion, one might mistake it for a true arrival in the celestial palace. Little does one know that the transcending of the mortal womb occurs within one’s own celestial palace atop the head. If one becomes attached and takes it for reality, failing to employ the method of transcendence, the yang spirit will remain within the body, and the embryonic immortal will not transform. One may then claim to have emerged above the dark paths, becoming an earthbound immortal, achieving longevity without death—but one cannot shed the mortal form to ascend as an immortal and return to the Three Isles as a celestial being. This is truly lamentable. Disciples must consider that though transcendence is difficult, it cannot be neglected.

The *Essentials of the Dao* states: The inexhaustible Dharma has already extinguished past faults.

**Transcendence: Tenth Method**

The *Golden Proclamation* states: The Dao is fundamentally non-being; to speak of it as being is not the Dao. The Dao is fundamentally void; to speak of it as substantial is not the Dao. Being formless, even questions and responses cannot apply to it. Being imageless, even seeing and hearing cannot apply to it. Taking the mysterious and subtle as the Dao, the mysterious and subtle still cannot escape the burdens of inquiry and perception. Taking the subtle and imperceptible as the Dao, one still cannot avoid the burdens of seeing and hearing. If even the subtle and imperceptible are not the Dao, then the Dao is also beyond knowing how it is so.

The *Jade Scripture* states: Its coming has a beginning, yet one does not know the beginning of the Great Dao. What is this? Its going has an end, yet one does not know the end of the Great Dao. What is this? Above the loftiest heights, though there is an "above," one does not know that above the Great Dao there is no limit. Below the deepest depths, though there is a "below," one does not know that below the Great Dao there is no end. Profound and unfathomable, it is called the Dao. It accords with what beings attain and arranges distinctions. The Dao of non-action cannot be exhausted.

The *True Formula* states: "Transcend" means transcending the mortal body to enter the ranks of sages. "Liberate" means shedding the mundane womb to become an immortal child.

chunks.original_text: 是其神入气胎，气全真诀。 须是前功节节见验正当，方居清静之室，以入希夷之境，内观认阳神，次起火降魔，焚身聚气。 真气升在天官，壳中清净，了无一物，当择幽居？ 一依内观。 三礼既毕，平身不须高升正坐，不须敛伸，闭目冥心。 静极朝元之后，身躯如在空中，神气飘然，难为制御，默然内观，明朗不昧，山川秀丽，楼阁依稀，紫气红光纷纭为阵，祥鸾彩凤音语如簧。 异景繁华，可谓壶中真趣，而洞天别景，逍遥自在，冥然不知有尘世之累。 是真空之际，其气自转，不须用法依时。 若见青气出东方，笙簧嘹喨，旌节车马，左右前后不知多少。 须臾南方赤气出，西方白气出，北方黑气出，中央黄气出。 五气结聚而为彩云，乐声嘈杂，喜气熙熙，金童玉女扶拥自身，或跨火龙，或乘玄鹤，或跨彩鸾，或骑猛虎。 升腾空中，自下而上，所遇之处，楼台观宇不能尽陈，神祇官吏不可备说。 又到一处，女乐万行，官僚班列，如人间帝王之仪，圣贤毕至。 当此之时，见之傍若无人，乘驾上升，以至一门，兵卫严肃而不可犯，左右前后官僚、女乐留恋不已，终是过门不得轩盖覆面，自上而下，复入旧居之地。 如此上下不厌其数，是调出壳之法也。 积日纯熟，一升而到天宫，一降而还旧处，上下绝无碍滞。 乃自下而上，如登七级宝塔，或如上三层红楼。 始也一级而一级，七级上尽，以至顶中，辄不得下视，神惊而恋躯不出。 既至七级之上，则闭目便好跳，如寐如寤，身外有身，形若婴儿，肌肤鲜洁，神采莹然，回观故躯，亦不见有所见之者，乃如粪堆。 又如枯木，憎愧万端，辄不可顿弃而远游。 盖其神出未熟，圣气结而未成，须是再入本躯，往来出入纯熟，一任遨游，始乎一步、二步，次二里、三里，积日纯熟，乃如壮士，展臂可千里、万里，而形神壮大，勇气坚固，然后寄凡骸於名山大川之中，从往来应世之外，不与俗类寺伦。 是此而或行满而受天书，骖鸾乘凤，跨虎骑龙，自东自西，以入紫府。 先见太微真君，次居下岛。 欲要升洞天，当传道、积行於人间。 受天书而升洞天，以为天仙。 凡行此法，古今少有成者。 盖以功不备而欲行之速、便为此道。 或乃功验未证，止事静坐，欲求超脱。 或乃阴灵不散，出而为鬼仙，人不见形，往来去住，终无所归，止於投胎就舍，而夺人躯壳，复得为人仙。 或出入不熟，往来无法，一去一来，无由再入本躯，神魂不知所在，乃释子坐化，道流之尸解也。 故行此道，乃在前功见验正当，仍是择地筑室，以远一切腥秽之物、臭恶之气、往来之声、女子之色，不止於触其真气，而神亦厌之。 既出而复入，入而不出，则形神俱妙，与天地齐年而浩劫不死。 既入而复出，出而不入，如蝉脱蜕，迁神入圣。 是以超凡脱俗，以为真人仙子，而在风尘之外、寄居三岛之洲者也。 已上超凡入圣之诀。 右大乘三门系天仙。 秘传正阳真人灵宝毕法卷下竟

When the spirit enters the qi-womb, the qi is complete in the true formula. Only when prior merits manifest verification at every stage may one dwell in a chamber of purity to enter the realm of the subtle and formless. There, one inwardly observes and recognizes the yang-spirit, then kindles the fire to subdue demons, burning the body to gather qi. The true qi ascends to the celestial palace, and within the shell, all is emptiness—nothing remains. Where to choose a secluded abode? Simply follow the practice of inward contemplation.

After the three bows are completed, sit upright without rising or adjusting posture, close the eyes, and still the mind. When stillness reaches its utmost and the primordial is invoked, the body seems suspended in space, the spirit and qi drifting freely, difficult to restrain. In silent inward contemplation, clarity shines unobscured: mountains and rivers appear resplendent, pavilions and towers faintly discernible. Purple qi and crimson light swirl in formation, auspicious simurghs and rainbow-feathered phoenixes sing with flute-like voices. Amidst such wondrous splendor—truly the delight of the alchemical crucible, a separate realm within the grotto-heaven—one roams carefree, oblivious to the burdens of the dusty world.

At this moment of true emptiness, the qi turns of itself, without need for method or adherence to time. If a blue-green qi emerges from the east, accompanied by the resonant strains of reed pipes and the procession of banners, chariots, and attendants—uncountable in number—before long, a crimson qi appears from the south, a white qi from the west, a black qi from the north, and a yellow qi from the center. The five qi converge to form radiant clouds, the air filled with joyous music and exuberant harmony. Golden lads and jade maidens escort one’s form, now riding a fiery dragon, now mounting a dark crane, now astride a rainbow phoenix, now bestriding a fierce tiger. Ascending into the void, rising from below, one traverses realms where towers and temples defy description, and divine officials and spirits surpass enumeration.

Arriving at another place, ten thousand rows of female musicians stand in array, officials ranked in order, like the court of an earthly emperor, with sages and worthies all in attendance. At this time, one remains unmoved by all around, ascending further until reaching a gate where guards stand solemn and inviolable. The officials and musicians linger behind, unable to follow, and as one passes through, a canopy veils the face. Descending once more, one returns to the former dwelling. Such ascent and descent occur countless times—this is the method of adjusting the spirit’s emergence from the shell.

With days of accumulated practice, one ascends directly to the celestial palace and descends back to the original place, moving freely without obstruction. The ascent begins from below, like climbing a seven-tiered pagoda or ascending a three-story crimson tower. At first, one ascends step by step, and upon reaching the seventh level, one must not look down, for the spirit, startled, clings to the body and refuses to depart. Only after reaching the summit may one leap with eyes closed, as if in dream or waking. A body exists outside the body, its form like an infant’s, skin fresh and radiant, spirit luminous. Looking back at the former shell, one sees nothing—only a heap of filth, a withered tree—shame and remorse arise, yet it cannot be abandoned at once for distant wandering.

For the spirit’s emergence is not yet perfected, and the sagely qi has not fully coalesced. One must re-enter the original body, mastering the art of coming and going until effortless. At first, one may wander but a step or two, then two or three *li*, and with accumulated practice, like a stalwart warrior, one may stretch an arm to traverse a thousand or ten thousand *li*. The spirit grows mighty, the form robust, and courage unshakable. Then one may entrust the mortal frame to the mountains and rivers, dwelling beyond the world’s responses, no longer mingling with the vulgar.

Thus, when merits are fulfilled, one receives the celestial writ, riding simurghs and phoenixes, straddling tigers and dragons, journeying east and west to enter the Purple Court. First, one meets the True Lord of the Grand Tenuity, then resides on the lower isles. To ascend to the grotto-heaven, one must transmit the Dao and accumulate merit among mortals. Receiving the celestial writ, one ascends to the grotto-heaven as a celestial immortal.

Few in ancient or modern times have succeeded in this practice, for many seek swift progress before merits are complete, or attempt transcendence through mere quiet sitting before verification is attained. Some, with lingering yin-spirits, emerge as ghost-immortals, unseen in form, wandering without destination, only to seize mortal shells and become human immortals. Others, unskilled in coming and going, lose the way back to their original body, their spirit adrift—this is the "sitting transformation" of Buddhist monks or the "corpse-liberation" of Daoist adepts.

Therefore, this practice demands that prior merits be verified at every stage. One must choose a site and construct a chamber, far from all foul odors, putrid vapors, worldly noises, and the allure of women, lest they disturb the true qi or repulse the spirit. If one emerges and re-enters, enters and does not emerge, then form and spirit attain perfection, enduring as long as heaven and earth, undying through eons. If one emerges and does not re-enter, like a cicada shedding its husk, the spirit ascends to sageliness—transcending the mortal and shedding the vulgar to become a true immortal, dwelling beyond the dusty world on the isles of the Three Mountains.

The above is the secret of transcending the mortal to enter sageliness.
The Great Vehicle’s Three Gates pertain to celestial immortals.
Here ends the *Secret Methods of the True Yang Immortal, Treasured Rites of the Numinous Treasure*, Scroll the Lower.
